reviewText:
Early Access Review

I do like this game. I really do, but please read on for my honest review.

When I first played I accidently killed my friend trying to defend him from a bear and got flagged as a murderer. Then some random yellow name came up and murdered me in return. He doesn't get flagged. He took all the apples I got from punching trees too. I was left with a fear of other players, a few twigs and an empty stomach.

There were buildings everywhere. Buildings with stone walls, buildings with wood walls and some with no walls. Then I saw these little smoking squares on the ground and tried to pick one up. 'Trace of Evil' it said. I didn't really know what it was, but I moved on and found a little flat piece of land to call my own. Starting to build was fun. I found it really exciting. The ideas were all worked out and despite the poor translation of many item names, I managed to figure things out really easily. The controls were pretty intuitive and I liked the idea of not tab targeting enemies.

Those kobolds really hurt when you're punching at them nude.

After I got a nice little tent set up, a campfire and a couple fences my red name turned back to yellow. Feeling a bit more comfortable, I ran off and started to explore, picking up all sorts of resources and coin to help me along the way. The night time was really rough, I didn't realize there would be so many zombies and skeletons attacking my tent. When morning came around I had managed to die a couple of times and could not figure out how to repair my tent.

Another yellow name came along, he had a full set of armor and backpack and adorable cat ears. I asked him how to repair my tent and he explained to me. Of course, you hold your money in your hand to repair a broken tent. Why didn't I think of that?

I thanked the kindness of this stranger, right up until he opened my tent and proceeded to take everything I had gathered, leaving me with two stacks of twigs and the firewood in my campfire. My stomach growled.

After I realized you could make locks, I never stopped. Tinkering became my hobby and I was really enjoying the torches and lanterns it provided. I moved to a new location that had more resources, because the runs to gather copper was draining.

My new place started to get some walls up and I had cabins, it was looking pretty good. A tiny farm, a few chickens, it was great until some neighbor moved in right next door. I had asked her why she kept trying to look at my locked tents and why she kept taking my chickens. She didn't speak any english but it looked like Portuguese when she responded, I'm not sure what she said. However, her town built up faster than mine and even though I invited some friends, I never really managed to get my walls closed before the real raids started.

It only took two of them, but without armor and strong weapons we were defenseless. They moved in, destroyed our walls, our cabins our gates. Flattened our fences and worktables. Stole water from our wells (I know now you -can- lock a well) and used it to run around and murder us repeatedly. After about an hour of this, they left us alone. I repaired, managed to get another crude knife, continued to go about my daily routine, though a little shaken up.

Then they did it again, this time with  more people. We were flattened in thirty seconds, murdered in less that and they proceeded to stick around and wait for us to respawn over and over again, scouring the woods and seeking us out to murder us some more for hours longer. I finally just logged out.

The next day, I went in to realize that there were traces of evil everywhere. The portuguese speaking woman had her base leveled and so did everyone else we could see.

Decided to move again.

After we moved, we had a great time. Skills were going up, we were trading, selling, making new friends. I had no problems with anyone but a few random rednames who tried to steal. Copper was harder to come by, but it was okay, I didn't mind spending over an hour to get an inventory full. I gave to the new players, helped my neighbors by repairing their walls, defending friends against an onslaught of raiders.

Then the griefers came again. A new town, a new place and new walls with a guild hall. At first I didn't believe it. Everything was stolen from once again. My towers had no arrows, my cabins were empty and even the tree I planted to look pretty, was chopped down. What was so shocking though was, all my walls were still intact.

Did they break in and take everything but was kind enough to repair the wall after they left? The gates were all locked as well, I was at a loss.

However, each night, the same happened again. This repeated for three days. (My livestock was stolen by my friendly" neighbors). On the fourth night I logged in about the time that the trace of evil had said and watched it. They weren't breaking down my walls
date:
they were ghosting through them! I had never seen that before. He just walked straight through and stayed yellow named as he proceeded to take everything again with a constant onlsaught of 'u mad bro?' and 'lol' as I watched.

I logged out and haven't been back online since.

The PvP of the game
recommended: doesn't bother me. I had no real qualms with the occasional raid
hoursPlayed: the occasional thief and even the yellow-name brazilians. What finally got on my nerves was the amount of consistant and repeated griefing that makes the game near unplayable. The straw that broke the camels back? The hacking. I have no idea how he did it or what exploit he was using
voteText: but there was no consequences for that person repeatedly taking from me and going around the system to do so.\n\nThe game is great
helpfulPercent: it's fun and if you want to risk it
votesHelpful: I would highly reccomend you do so. For the price? Not so much. The upgrade gets you a tiny little backpack and a hairstyle
votesTotal: it's not worth it. It is not worth its current list price

even at early access.

I know the developers are working on it. They are a team of three with only one community advisor to translate for them. They threw their game to the sharks and the players are feeding. I'm sure they did not realize what horrors would transpire as they put their game on Steam.

It is too early though."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IMPORTANT NOTICE: You can't have a neutral review, so I've chosen negative. I'm not telling you to not play Tree of Life, just informing you of what you'll face if you decide to play it. Thanks.

I used to have a great property in the desert, surrounded by wooden walls, it was pretty... And it felt secured. I had all my crafting skills maxed out, good neighbours, I've even had a bull for 2 hours before someone stole it while I was mining, but I didn't really mind, I was not a traveller. I had seeds for every plants, every crafting stations, a huge stockpile of rocks and logs for those in need. I had towers filled with arrows to protect my camp from monsters. I had two animals of each kind in my small farm so I could get eggs, milk, etc without searching for hours outside. Sweet memories.

And then, two things happened.

One day, a guild arrived in the desert and began to plant swamp trees. After less than a week, the whole desert had been polluted by those trees, it didn't look like a desert anymore. You can always cut trees, I said to myself, so I didn't care that much. But my friendly neighbours simply left the game for that. Oh well, I said to myself, someone else will eventually settle there.

Later, one member of this guild came to my camp and asked for some help. I gladly accepted to help them build walls, I had a lot of rocks and limestones anyway. So I took all my limestones, closed the door behind me, went to their camp and worked there for an hour or so. This guy thanked me and I went back to my place. The thing is, my place wasn't here anymore. While I was helping him, other members of the said guild raided my cute little camp. They had destroyed my walls, towers, lockpicked all my storages. They had killed all of my animals, destroyed my fields, and they had thrown everything on the ground to make it despawn. I've helped them during one hour, and they have returned me the favor by ruining a mounth of hard work.

Of course at first I was very angry, so I took out my sword and killed them all, green and red players alike. They didn't expect this at all, so they didn't fight back. After my rampage, I simply gave up on playing. I didn't want to spend a whole week building a new camp with those guys around. Also, I had turned red for the first time of my short life, so they would have just killed me over and over again, my armor and sword weren't infinite... So I have just stoped playing. Thanks to them, I have a social life now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is, as it stands, a good game. It's a good game. You run around, you pick up sticks, you make little houses and ride cows. What's not to like? The game's got charm in spades, and it's fun for about 12 hours. After those 12 hours, you have a problem if you want to keep your stuff. I'm not going to say it's impossible, but it's very hard. You don't get walls until Carpentry 18 and even then they're not very effective. You don't get locks until tinkering 14 and that's if you're lucky enough to find iron which, for me, took a total of four hours.

Even then, the locks do nothing. People will destroy your houses, and I've seen this pretty much everywhere. If you're not in a guild or a relatively large group, your buildings will be destroyed shortly after you log off. Don't leave any farms growing either, they'll often be taken. Your mounts? Not locked to an individual, so they can be ridden away by anyone that wanders by. But that's not the worst part.

I was attacked by reds shortly after starting the game, and that was FINE. That's a fair fight, where I'm innocent and you're the aggressor. What's annoying are the reds and yellows that work together. The reds distract you while the yellows look through everything in your town that you can take. If you attack and kill them, you get turned red, which is what they want so they get full loot rights because you're a 'murderer'. It's not the strategy that bothers me, it's having a game so poorly guess moral choices when it gives us no laws. We're not protected, so until I get locks on every house, anyone can just grab anything. My towers? Pitiful damage that red players can casually stroll through. And that's just for a handful of people that just felt like bothering someone else.

The hamlet I built will probably be gone by tomorrow, that's fine. I'll remember the fun I had before I was tricked and killed by two random people that were passing by. It's still a good game, it's like wurm and harvest moon had a baby, but I feel like will never effectively protect my belongings without being part of a much larger town, and that sucks. So I won't be playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've never felt so alone playing an online game.

So why are there so many positive reviews?
Because the developers gave permanent extra inventory slots and a hair style to the people that wrote a positive review.

The game is in Early Acces. With it comes the usual crappy client issues like unexplained fps drops, screen tearing, client crashes, but that's the least of your worries.

I really wanted to like the game, but I'm afraid it's very dull, featureless, boring, repetative, flawed and most importantly - time consuming.

Let's start with the major flaws:
There is no party chat or global chat or guild chat. Wait! There is no party in the game. The sole guild feature in the game is that you can use your guild members' buildings if they put a guild lock on it. So where are your friends in the world? Ask them on Skype or Teamspeak, cuz there is no other way to find out. So for an online game, it's amazing how antisocial this game is, and how hard it is to play with others. And make no mistake. This is NOT a game you can solo, unless you play like 70 hours for the first 4-5 days, and at least 3 hours every day after that.

Night and day follow each other in quick succession. Night time is so dark, that you literally can't see anything. I'm not joking. It's pitch black. Seriously. Black. This means that you either spend LOTS of resources on lightning (which is very dumb) or you limit yourself to tasks that don't require moving or seeing (standing 10 minutes crafting, harvesting lumber or stone). If you try to do anything else then you'll be GREATLY penalized.

Traveling is superslow, superboring, superblehI'lljustaltf4.
But you'll need to travel, because certain resources like lava sculpture" (red ore) or corn or whatever is not found in your home biome. Let me translate:
You want to get lava? Push WWWWW for 10 minutes. Look at a completely black screen (night) for 10 minutes. Do some mining
date: then head back and push the same boring WWWWW for 20 minutes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR: This game has a ton of potential but needs some serious work. My recommendation is to wait at least a couple of months.

I don't believe I can recommend this product at this time. Perhaps, after a couple more months of patching and refining, I will be able to change my rating, but there is a lot to be done before then. Let me be perfectly honest here, I enjoyed this game thoroughly, for a while, at least. The following is my specific tale in this game so far:

The beginning of my play through started with me wandering one of the starter isles in the pitch black of night, bumping into murderously slap-happy zombies and skeletons. Armed only with my karate pokes of justice, I quickly learned that fleeing was the best strategy. One of my friends soon arrived on a stolen bull with a saddle and soon led me to a nearby encampment where i could steal one for myself. Now riding our trusty beeves, we rode off into the wilds looking for this base my friend assured me was safe for us.

We crossed many different terrains on our way to the promised lands, from mesas to geyser fields to forests to crevasses, the land certainly wasn't the same looking for very long. It is at this time that I encountered the first of many bugs: My friend started randomly and rapidly taking damage whilst riding his trusty mobile steak platform and soon died. He dropped all of his stuff and became a spooky ghosty. This was no big deal at that moment because there was no one else around to steal any of his stuff so he quickly repossessed his now slightly used corpse and we continued on our journey.

We finally reached the base after about 45 minutes of travelling in circles and around hills, mostly because my friend relied on his memory to guide us instead of the coordinates he had copied down. They welcomed us fully into their guild and we had a place to rest at last. We quickly started working for our keep in our own ways: I was a tree puncher and log hauler, while my friend worked on his tinkering and rapidly became the resident Batman, what with his useful gadgets that he whipped out like locks for houses and lanterns.

Night descends rapidly and rather frequently in this game, and it gets dark. As my least favorite Pyromancer in Game of Thrones says: The Night is dark and full of Terrors." Zombies and skeletons are attracted to settlements and bases; the larger the base
date: the more they attack and it wasn't long before houses started to collapse from the undead onslaught. We would fight off the invaders as best we could

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I began this game a few days after launch and through it was quite fun.  Lots of things to do, enemies to kill, and levels to be gained.  20 hours went by and I was addicted. Then patch after patch came through. Items got nerfed, pvp became corrupt, evil guilds started wrecking havoc on honest people trying to enjoy the game without penalty.

I still continued to play as i had made friends and wanted to grow.  After about 80 hours, I capped out my levels.  Realized that the world was quite small, the amount of enemies was incredibly smaller, grinding enemies proved to be worthless as enemies dropped only copper/silver/gold, linen, and a rare worthless mask.

Money is worthless in the game. Everyone tended to craft their own items, or have a guild mate craft them. As soon as you bought an item, a better one would be crafted making yours obsolete, and left to be dropped on the ground.

The biggest grief of the whole game is the sheer time it takes to build a fortress, wood walls, stone walls, towers galore, only to have a single point in the wall broken and all your loot ravaged. Lock Picking is too easy. The penalty for thieving/murdering/pillaging is non existant due to a broke pvp mechanic.

80 Hours of building can be destroyed in minutes of harrassment.

In my opinion, the biggest killer of the game was a patch that reduced the durability on end game items so drastically that they were not even worth crafting. In addition, armor had durability which ended adventurers trying to make a living by grinding enemies. Hours and Hours dedicated to crafting end game gear, only for it to be nerfed to something of a joke.

Not to mention, the game lags incredibly bad now.

Thats my rant.  I rated the game an A+ near launch, and easily left to a flat F now.  Server populations have to be about 10 people at any one time. A huge drop from launch. You would see hundreds of people. Now you literally have to search far and wide for someone. And when you do, its usually just someone reminiscing of the past when the game was alive, looking at a burning destroyed fort that once thrived.

Take my advice and dont waste your time here.

Fun game.  Very fun game, infact.  The crafting mechanic is nicely implemented and was one of the reasons I bought the game.

I should have done some research on the community.  This community acts like a surivival-game version of EVE's community.  If you're not affiliated with some alliance, or friends with an alliance's father's brother's nephew's cousin's former roomate, well then you're screwed.  You will be killed (or have a high chance of it).

If this game ever institutes private hosted servers (like ARK), then I will change this review to an Thumb Up.  Until then, however, it will not be recommened by me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

::Disclaimer::

Unlike the hundreds of other reviews before mine, I want to publically state; I am not being paid or sponsored by anyone to write a review. Apparently, previous reviewers have been given copies of the DLC upgrade in exchange for reviews. Just wanted to put it out there, I am not one of them. I write this, because I purchased the game and I felt it important to write a review to educate and inform others of my experience.

Imagine, 7 days to die(without zombies), mixed with Minecraft(without the blocky graphics), topped off with Harvest Moon. Yep, that is Tree of Life in a nutshell. It has aspects of all three games, making it fun, addictive, and exciting. A Crafting-Survival game, or at least it should be. The game bills itself as a crafting-survival game in a multiplayer world, where you can work with others to create communities; However, Earlier notices from game developers indicated that PVP would play a small part of the overall experience, but that the game was about crafting and survival and would be largely PVE in nature. This unfortunately, does not appear to be the case with this game.

Grief of Life, or Tree of Grief as it is being billed in some online discussion threads, places you on a very large, open world island, with multiple biomes. where you are pitted against the islands inhabitants, and the strange creatures that emerge from the shadows at night. Build structures for safety as fast as you can, but beware creatures as well as other players can and will bust up your fort. The Game currently utilizes a Criminal Flagging system. Criminal flagging is earned by attacking other players and/or their structures. As a Criminal flagged red, you are unable to approach other cities or player watchtowers without automatically being attacked. Also as a criminal, anyone is free to attack you without reprecussions or negative consequences. Once a red player is killed, their backpack can be looted. Since the Criminal flag lasts a number of realtime minutes/hours, this has led to abuses of the flagging system, where neutral players camp and grief them without any reprecussions, going as far as preventing those characters from materializing after death, because they are instantly killed once they resurrect. Yellow players are neutral, and have the option to be a trolling ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, or not. They can go near player encampments without being attacked, If a yellow tagged player is killed, they do not lose their belongings, but it is always best to stay cautious when around neutral players. Neutral players can also build in and around your cities, limiting where you can build. They are also capable of stealing your crops, and your livestock, as well as anything not bolted down with locks, without any sort of reprecussions. You have no way of removing them from your area, without flagging yourself as a criminal.

It is still in Alpha testing and there are some bugs, clipping issues etc,  just from the initial experience I've had playing, Tree of Life is definitely a game to look out for as a goto crafting-survival in the future, assuming they are willing to fix some of the major flaws surrounding PVP and Griefing. I saw massive potential with Tree of Life and originally intended on giving it a thumbs up review, because I saw just how much fun the game could be. Unfortunately right now, it appears the game is overrun with a segment of the gaming community who thinks the entire game should be a pvp battleground and wants to change the nature of the game. They are also willing to attack anyone off-game, who disagrees with their interpretation of how the game should be.

The development team, while initially speaking out against griefing and abusive PVP play, have since remained quiet and appear to be hedging their bets on which way they will take the game in the future. So if you are interested in playing with others on a game where cooperation is encouraged and general ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•-baggery is frowned upon, this is currently not the game for you. If you are all about wallowing in a PVP Litterbox and want a game where you can free for all against other players without any serious reprecussions, even to the point of being able to play-obstruct others, in a wild west Douchefest, this game is right up your alley. Unfortuantely, If the game isn't changed to prevent player abuse, or at the very least properly labelled for the PVP Litterbox it is, there will be thousands of people very dissatisfied and disapointed with what could have been the go-to game for crafting-survival sandbox multiplayer game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game shows promise, but the updates come as slow as molasses and the player base is slowly dieing, making the game less and less interesting. The few players you will find are usually griefers.

If you plan on maintaining a base in this game, try to have a group. Maintaining a base as a solo player will take you 30 mins to 1 hour daily of upkeep or you risk losing all your stuff. Even then a group of griefers could decide they don't like you and wreck everything you own.

I enjoyed this game in the beginning but the slow death of the server population and the nonchalant update schedule lead me to leave this negative review. Hopefully future updates can breath life into the game and bring back a more healthy player population.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not going to leave as long of a review as others, however the exploiting of the flagging system totally breaks this game for myself and my friends.

Basically what happens now is someone runs up to your gates, unlocks them. Then runs away while their flag drops. Then they run in free of attack to take/look at everything you have. If you lock your buildings they do the same thing. They lockpick and then run away for their flag to drop. Right now there is a bug that allows someone that is blue(good) to unlock your gates/buildings and as long as they don't move they won't get attacked by your 100 towers you built up. So that's what people do.

When you do find someone that is in your city and killing your farms, workbenches, animals, etc... you kill them and then you become flagged. Once you are red not even your own towers will protect you from harms way. All due to you trying to protect your city.

The population is super low. On a busy night we might see 5-6 people while traveling the whole map of broken/abandoned cities.

Anyway my friends and I are moving on, though we gave our money so I guess it really means nothing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey guys,

Some of you have played the game.  Hopefully you have.  Some of you have yet to play, and are reading reviews to determine if the game is worth spending the money on.

Well, as of today I'm sitting at somewhere near 250 hours played.  Hardly a long time compared to some who play this, but certainly longer than many.  I wanted to share my thoughts about the game in as objective a way as I can possibly do.  I do like the game though, so I have to be honest when I admit that I am hoping you give the game a really good shot.  I will explain.

This game is tagged as an Early Access Massively Multiplayer Survival PvP RpG Sandbox.  Now I feel it necessary to break that down a little bit to explain each part and how it pertains to Tree of Life specifically.

I write this review based on my experience on the NA server.

Early Access.
Tree of Life is Early Access.  I need to stress how important it is that everyone who plays this game remembers this fact.
We have paid to get involved in the games development.  That has lots of perks, like getting to know the game inside and out, before it goes live, and they have told the players we get to keep our characters during any major changes that will happen through the process.  This gives long standing players a good individual advantage.  But everything with a positive, has a negative.  For example, any change they accept, or decide to do, will impact everyone.  So if they make a decision based on one persons recommendation, it affects every player.

Massively Multiplayer.
So we all know this.  In Tree of Life, the game had thousands of players who got impatient or interested in other newer games and left Tree of Life for shinier things.  It's ok they did because now is a great time to get into the game and start building a fort for yourself.  With all the old players gone and their forts destroyed there is loads of free space to work with and start training up your skills.

PvP
There is a very interesting PvP dynamic to the game, though due to a recent decline in player population, the PvP is really minimal.  Most of the remaining players whom I've met have no desire to cause trouble and actually focus on building care packages or helping out newbies.  The early learning curve is a bit tricky but with help from your peers, it becomes much easier.

RPG
Currently there are limited elements for roleplaying.  There are very basic social actions and only a local chat.  This is easily circumvented with Steam friendships or voice chat amongst friends.  Not a deal breaker in my mind, though some extra chat functions would be a nice addition to the game.  I'm not sure where their goals are here but it doesn't change the fact that this game does lack many RPG elements.  There are no quests or missions and no NPC's to speak with or trade with.  Considering the game is in early access and they are still writing code, I expect this will change once they add Monster Villages to the game in the next couple weeks.

Sandbox
As far as Sandbox goes, you even get to make a shovel to dig in the sand!  You build stuff.  You build more stuff.  You gather resources and build even more stuff.  It's never ending, but that's the grind.  It isn't fun for everyone, and with the lack of other material it can become really tedious at times.  Still, I find it rewarding to make stuff for my friends or design walls of a fort.  There are certainly some enormous forts in the game.  Impressive constructions that's for sure.


Many are concerned about Stability with an early access game.  I have only experienced one or two crashes since I started playing, and the FPS is good so long as I don't come across a fort with 30,000 sections of wall in construction.  The game has lots of potential and I know you can easily get a couple hundred hours of play.  Check out their website and official forums for more information.

I want to give a rating but since I have limited experience with early access sandbox titles, my rating wouldn't be objective.  So, I'll just give it a thumbs up and hope to see you in game sometime.

Cheers

Skrem

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would not recommend this game at this time.

Pros
Very stable to run.
PVE mobs provide a challenge from Wildlife to monsters.
Crafting is excellent.
Full Loot PVP only if the person is red(Criminal)
Resources are not abuntant which will cause fights over territories.
You don't ever actually own livestock or Farms.

Cons
Self Centered community.   I have yet to even find any helpful players.
Cannot Build in peace.   THere are always people greifing and you have no way to stop it.  Between fences, towers, walls, livestock and farms getting taken or destroyed.  There is little to no ability to stop any theifs without others players/friends to assist.,
Your own towers will attack and kill you even if you are defending your livestock from an attacker that is not flagged as a crimanl while in your home base.


This game has potential, just there is not enough of a community to make this worthwhile.   You cannot play this game solo unless you are well geared and have stone walls and towers.  Be prepared to be ganked even if you are tagged yellow or neutral.   The defenses are a joke and your base is open to anyone no matter what.  Locks, towers really don't discourage greifers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The graphics and audio are pleasing and the game play is fairly fun. The control system has clearly been designed with future mobile support in mind which tends to make it a little bit counter intuitive; it still needs to be polished. There are also some annoying bugs that are hard to pin down, such as tooltips failing to work and so forth. All of these however are to be expected for an early access game and shouldn't discourage anyone from trying the game out.

There are, however, several key design flaws to the gameplay that lead me to not recommend getting this game while it is still in earlier access. My wife and I tried playing together and found that anything we built was most likely destroyed the next time we logged in. It was also almost impossible to find open land to build on as the world is quite crowded. In addition to the frustration of having anything you build be destroyed there are many situations that can arise in the gameplay that can prevent you from being able to play.

I logged in after having not played in two weeks and found myself inside someone's base. I can't escape the base in any way. I didn't want to try to knock down any walls as I did not want to develop a criminal record. After waiting for a long time hoping a player with access to the base would open the gate I conceded that I would have to try to knock down a wall to escape, despite not wanting a criminal record. I am unable to attack any part of the walls, however, without being quickly killed by the base's arrow towers. I am now effectively stuck in the base with no way to escape or play the game. Until these types of large design flaws are addressed I would advise against paying for this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is a very solid game, for being early release.

The Bad:
-Hit boxes and targeting enemies is horrid, the worst aspect to this game.  Hopefully this will be an easy fix.  having a log attack you endlessly and not being able to even target it is frustrating.
- Lots of grinding to raise levels
-Bad translations to English


The Good:
-With friends, this game is very fun and feels like building a town.  You can war with neighbors, make peace, build impressive structures.
-Lots of potential
-Not typical survival game

I would recommend this game, if you can convince friends to buy it too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game needs A LOT OF WORK! The night/day turn around is way to fast, ridicously so. You spend ALL your time trying to get food or you get sick and die while fighting wolvev, tree people, skeletons, zombies AND let's not forget the stupid people that camp on you and kill you repeatedly for nothing when you've only been in game for 2 days.

The speed in which day turns to night is not realistic and you don't have enough time gather food and firewood  to make it through the night unless you have a group of 4 or more. Forget building because as soon as you try, the skeleton crew comes at night to destroy what you attempted to make while you are trying to keep your fires going and eat.

Being turned into a criminal while defending your camp? What the hell is that? Then the idiots camp there, shouting and laughing and wait till you come back just to kill you again. THEY don't turn red; they didn't turn red, stole all my stuff and trashed the camp.

Makes me not want to play at all. There has to be some ground to gain. When you get beat down constantly it isn't worth even trying.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Day 1: I landed on the beach, walked around and punched a few things whilst getting the handle on the systems of the game. I had built a little hut to shield myself from the cold whilst only occasionally having someone new attack it before being mobbed by everyone else.

Day 2: I started to grow crops before they were almost immediately pillaged by people who didn't understand how growing works in a game as they destroyed them and any resources the crops would have given.

Day 3: It was something on the breeze that gave me bad vibes... Something was coming and I didn't know what. I chose to move inland some more, in hopes of getting away from the swarms of new players and in the hopes of setting up a new home that wont get attacked every 5 minutes, led by instinct to the other side of the main land...

Day 4: My fears come to light, a rumbling from the tutorial island can be heard as hundreds and hundreds of Russians landed on the beach... Every town destroyed in there wake... Homes pillaged. Homes Destroyed. Fire reached the horizon as the defining battle cry of the Russians came towards us. And as they got closer we learned what they were chanting...

BLYAT! BLYAT! BLYAT!

God save us all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life, the type of sandbox game I enjoy most. Quirky, laid back music, practicing Wing Chun on trees, punching veins, punching Chickens, punching Kobolds, getting punched by Zombies. Makes punching better than Minecraft!


Okay, let's get serious.

For an early access game, I did not expect much. Being a huge fan of sandbox games, Tree of Life holds a lot of promise and the game is already delivering. So far, I have not encountered any bugs and/or glitches in the game, which surprises me. If music is a big deal for you, then this game is just right. Truth be told, if I can get my hands on Tree of Life's soundtrack, I'd buy it. 10/10. It's that good.

As far as the community in the game goes, I'm fortunate enough to have friends who actually play the game, but I've met some pretty cool people so far and have had little conflict with others. If roleplaying is your thing, there are some villages that encourage roleplay. If you just want to play the game as is, there's always that too. There's already a lot to do in the game, so I'm excited to see what else the devs have in store for us!

The only thing I don't like is that there's a delay when you're trying to switch to a bandage after swinging a melee weapon. Granted, this isn't much of a big deal and can easily adjust to, but I don't know if it's intentional to make the game semi-realistic or if there's just a delay. Either way, it's just something I was curious about.

Overall:
If you enjoy sandbox games, cartoony graphics, amazing music, and using a chicken as a punching bag, Tree of Life is definitely for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a fun game in general. Surviving, building, fishing, farming, crafting and basically creating a little community, but it sucks that the bigger players/communities screw over the smaller ones. They can basically do anything to smaller villages/players, without any consequences. There is a criminal point system, but they can't be bothered.

So it is fun to play but like other online games, better/earlier players can, and definitely will, screw you over big time. Everything you gathered will be stolen and if you put a bounty on them, their teammates will kill them so it's a win/win for them.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-PVE: There's a primal thrill to running through the jungle like some latter-day Tarzan, but if you're serious about staying alive then sooner or later you'll want to build some form of shelter. Community base building is required and it's easy to make friends because peeps are friendly. Getting food is really easy to keep up with as in for now.

-PVP: Game has an MMORPG system of red/Yellow names. If you kill someone or destroy anything you end up having a red name and if someone kill you while red you will drop everything. On the other hand if you r a yellow name you would only drop one item and it's usually stick or pants. It's fun when it's group vs group in the EU server. You also don't respawn but turn into a ghost thing to come back to the place you at. There is blocking and shield bash or parry not sure yet.

-NOTE: There is an ideal balance between PVP and PVE, mostly PVE though like GRAV game style. Unlike other survival games, you would feel safe in Tree of Life.

-GRAPHICS: I like to zoom in real close to my char in this game while running and attack, playing general and it's real nice and colorful. The game looks like a new Runescape and zelda thing. I disliked how it looked over Youtube videos at first but the art style is just fit in game. Players male models are huge tho.

-OPTIMIZATION: The game doesn't feel like an early access game what so ever.

-END GAME: White iron armor is beautiful with an axe and you can ride bulls. Map is huge and progressing along with other players killing mobs is quite fun. Grinding and leveling up everything is noticeable is worth a while, Tree of Life might seem like a standard, open-world survival, but there are a few gameplay mechanics and ideal decisions made that make it perfect. Players and friends have what seem to be an endless map to explore while constructing shelter bases and keeping peace still to survive. The world is harsh and PVP is worse, this is why leveling stats is worth a while to protect your potato farm.

-NOTE: Devs listen. All though they didnt fade the map as a suggestion of mine. They lowered the leveling of carpenter and made fences and locks easy to get early games and more as people complained about @forums you can see yourself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 158 hours in this game, I will say - don't ever think it's a minecraft-stylish game kids. It's a cruel gameworld with people can destory your hard-working in 10 mins. If you love to build your dream house or love to farm/feeding animals etc, please continue with your Minecraft and that's still the best ever sandbox game so far.

PVP system is imbalance in this game at the moment (by the time I wrote this review at least). People with high level gear can destory the stone wall within 1 min. You have to spend at least 1 week (maybe 40 hours) to build your own garrison. Oh yeah, you have to worry when people will rob you too. There is no actual punishment for these crimial unless you could kill a def 640+ red name but no matter what, you need some friends to accompany you if you wanna have fun.

PVE part - well I cant see the PVE part since the PVP system has already destoryed this game.

From my experience, I spent like 16 hours a day, even in my working hour to guard the camp and ensure no mobs from the evening will break the wall (oh yeah, they can break your stone wall within 2 nights and arrow towers sometimes cannot hit them even it placed in front of it or there's one next with it lol). I also have to worry when the Russians will come that make my life stressful enough :P (being robbed quite a lot and all Russians so far, soz Russians in EU)

Anyway, it's a game that still developing so I couldn't say it sucks but just take time to be a full game :))

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game has potential, it is enjoyable and relaxing but - there is a little but.
1. As I write now - it has a mastery bug, it has a dupe bug and it has glitching thorough walls bug. So you are not safe whatever you do. Your lifestock is not safe. Your mounts are not safe. If you dont have any inside defence - your stuff is not safe too.
2. Servers are empty, 90% of peoples already left with taste of disappointment i guess. If you are teamplayer you might find it difficult to find some company.
3. Community is pretty toxic - there are good peoples out there there but from my experience 7/10 will rob you, kill you or..just follow you to your base and raid you using exploits and bugs.
4. Griefing - seems like peoples here do nothing but camping and stalking fresh spawns, so before playing take a pill of Valium.

Game itself is good, and like i said it has potential to be even better, although I cannot recommend it to anyone in it's current state of development. If bugs and exploits will be fixed then maybe I'll can change my review. I know - most of peoples are saying - it's early access, they are right. But it is 1st time when I bought ea game, where players are pointing problems, adressing it multiple times to devs and using any possible channel to make them fix exploits / bugs and there is no word from dev's for weeks. Not a single word. Well, I will look further for game development but at current state I say : NOT RECOMMENDED, DON'T BUY IT UNTIL IT IS FIXED AND PLAYABLE.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSo, first off. This game has its issues, but it's pretty fantastic. The game is a bit grindy, seeing as it's Korean in origin, that didn't surprise me right off the bat. What did surprise me was an incredible early access game, that has had me playing for nearly 6-7+ hours a day since the minute I added it to my Steam Library. The game, at first glance, seems typical of most survival type early access games currently on the market, and you would think the only difference is it's choice in art style, well.. that's not quite the case. This game, is relatively similar to other survival games (ie. Build a base, sustain it, defend it, pvp, raid, etc.) but, it has some great RPG elements, like actual leveling up, hard stats such as INT, STR, DEX and CONS that most of us RPG players are used to. The game has a kind of Runescape mixed with Rust type of vibe to it, it seems very open ended with no short of things to do and I personally love it. The dev team for the game is small but dedicated, and I'm excited to see where this game goes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OLD REVIEW. Will update in-time.
--------------------------------------------------

-Short, first time experience review (2 hours played)-

I'll be going through a few quick things I've experienced this far into the game. Both some positive and negative ones.

-------Positive-------

-On the positive side I find the game very charming to it's current surrounding environments. There's a lot of different kind of places in this huge world to explore. Making it interesting to see where and how communities will grow up along the world later on in the long run.

-I haven't progressed too much with the skill system this far. But I see that reaching different professions will take a good while and a lot of time spent on each skill. An interesting way to go about the development of your character.

-Sadly enough I haven't manage to get much further with the game to experience and learn about other positive things, and I'll tell ya why.

-------Negative-------

-Oh boy, here we got a few negative things to worry about. First off, I see that the developers wants the players to figure out pretty much.. everything through their first hour into the game. And yes I know there's a few guides to read to help ya out. But even the help of the guides can still make things seem confusing to understand. Especially when you wanna start out right away. There's no simple way to indicate what you exactly have to do to start making that.. that.. that and that. You get my drill. Once you start experimenting, you eventually start to understand how things works. Tho it's not an easy guess at first and can become a little frustrating for some.

-I found myself at the end of my first game session very frustrated and somewhat disappointed. Throughout my session I found myself constantly being attacked by invisible creatures. Both under day and night time. Most of the time I heard skeleton rumbling noises approaching and then the situation would proceed with me losing tons of health, one hit at the time. Forcing me to leave my current settlement... forever. I experienced this on the EU server and from the little I read in the discussion thread not long after the end of my game session, other people had experienced the same problem. It's a very huge issue that must be dealt with immediately! The game is practically unplayable at this time. As you can't see or attack these invisible creatures! Very disappointed to see an NPC being bugged. Perhaps? Especially at this time at the launch on Steam.

-And of course, just as I spawned in at the very beginning, I were attacked by another player. Not saying it's a complete negative issue. After all, it's a mix of MMO and PVP. Perhaps it's just me who doesn't like being attacked just as I spawn in, into a new game that I've never played before..

-------First experience conclusion-------

So far the game feels promising and it has potential to improve a lot. Tho, the major issues such as the invisible creatures must be dealt with as soon as possible. 50% of the experience is being ruined due to this problem and making it somewhat unplayable right now. Especially if you wanna settle down somewhere.
Tho, as I have looked forward to this game for some time now, I can't go too harsh on it. It's still in development and I hope the developers fix and update the game often to improve it's current.. minor issues.

-That's all I had to say, hope this little review helped!-

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Howdy!

First off, I'd like to say this is a great game if you're playing with a group of people.
I have recruited and played with 30+ people, and all of them are nice guys, none of them are trolls, and they're all really friendly.
I cannot take part in how hard this game would be in the absence of good people, but I can tell you about the game mechanics themselves.

The Bad:

-Translations are HORRID. It's painful to read through the itemnames and descriptions. It's easy to see what the items are, but its still painful.
-You can walk up 75 degree cliffs.
-Trolls and greifers are existent. It's a sandbox MMO, and early access at that, so it's inevitable. But tolerable.
-Crafting is a GRIND! But not intolerably so.
-There needs to be more early storage options. Chests and whatnot.

The Good:

Now for the good parts!

-Music is AMAZING. Feels like your playing harvest moon the whole time, and doesn't feel repetitive.
-The PvP, in my opinion, is spot on. While a lot of people are complaining about it, it's not as big a deal as they are making it out to be. It is annoying to die, but you only lose one item.
If you're of average intelligence, you won't be baited into turning yourself into pvp-flagged.
-Crafting feels USEFUL.


It's a great game if your playing with people, but I can tell that it would be a giant pain in the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to play alone.
Don't buy this game if you get irritated quickly, can't relax, or take the time to enjoy the little things.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There are plenty of other reviews out there including huge threads of people going back and forth on their ideas of what the game should be about. I believe they do much better of a job giving a idea of how the game is in its current state along with how I feel. Like many other people I feel that this game is a tad bit enjoyable for the social aspect along with having a interesting path to make the game really enjoyable as a PVE sandbox. The addition of NPC towns and NPC raids makes me rather hopeful that at one point the creators could even include basic open world dugeons to keep things interesting.

At this point, there really is only the bar bones in the game to waist your time on. You grind and grind the same buildings or objects to gain level while those items have very little useable value when you are making a small place for yourself. The first town I was ever a part of had dozens of stoves, campfires, work benchs, and other such buildings just cluttering up the space we had. This is slightly an okay system as later levels of crafting seems to be designed to work off one another's talents. An example is to have one person a high enough carpenter to create a blacksmith station for someone to take over making weapons and some armor. That same person or another can create the tailor station, walls, and other buildings to let people focus on speciality roles. The whole system just feels so simple while also being unique to bring communities together.

The PVE in the game is so interesting and refreshing that I have to regret that I can't give the game a good rating at this time. At this time, it seems like the majority of the game is plagued by grefers that exploit flaw and bugs to become a pain. This is why I would suggest looking through a few of the discussions that is littered all over the fourms to get an idea of the different groups and how bad they are for one another. It gets to the point that I can't even agree with the people who would rather see the game try and fix the criminal flagging system. There are still a few indiviuals that I believe have the right idea and want to see a more balanced approach, but at this moment I would hold off two months if not more before checking back on the pop/attitude that is in the game at that moment. I'm stuck with the game at the moment because of the grind that caused me to go way over the two hour limit that is on the return policy at the time. I'll just keep this one on the shelf until then and change my review if things change for the better.

Edit:
Odd, it seems like my last revision didn't stick for some reason. The only thing to take from what I had to say is that some of the positive reviews from the first week of the game release was due to a promotion that the company was having. This is kind of a slight worning and explination on why some of the positive reviews may be simple one line messages that says nothing about the game itself.

I mentioned earlier about there being better reviews to look up for pros and cons on the game. Well, two of the reviews that seemed to paint a nice picture ended up somehow way below in the rating. It might be good to just follow the links to see them since I really think they should be above mine.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My biggest problem with this game is how it's anti-solo. You'll be hard pressed to enjoy the game without either playing with friends, or making friends, because anyone can come up and take your hard earned stuff. Plus, it takes ages to build your skills up to do even the most basic things. For example, if you want to start Blacksmithing, you need to level like 5 other skills before you can even start on smithing.

It is fairly fun though, and it still has a pretty long ways to go, so it's worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Im not one for writing reviews normally, but this game blew me away.
In my quest to find the Perfect Sandbox MMO for me and my circle of friends to play, I stumbled upon this gem.

A very intimate medieval themed crafting system, with a unique world leads to this being a very deep and rewarding MMO. Your typical MMO stats (HP, MP, Energy) are increased through the leveling of your own personal skills. For example, every level of the Farming and Unarmed skill you rank up, you gain 1 CON(stitution) in turn which increase your health by one point. That may seem mundane but skills level up relativley fast in this MMO and you are rewarded a bonus stat of the same or different attribute every four levels.

Progression and technology is not an easy thing to obtain therefore requiring cooperation on small to massive scales, and because of the way these mechanics are set up, players are unusally friendly and helpful! Beware though, most will stop at nothing to take revenge if you steal from them, especially those with their own guild. You dont need ten people to start a succesful group in this game, infact with that many people it may be hard to start out, given that Food is a serious requirment in this MMO. Yes, I know, an MMO that requires food? I realize that no one signed up to play farmville, but agriculture and hunting/foarging is another aspect of this game. Being hungry doesnt lead to you dying, rather it reduces your Stamina, chance to dodge and move speed. In a game as large and dangerous as this one, the loss of those three stats is crippling. On the bright side, food is not hard to come by in the least.


For the price of $22 Canadian Dollars, i feel like this game was a steal.
Farewell and goodluck travellers, I hope to see you in game!

If u love building $hits, making friends, screw over ur guildmates just to have fun and this maybe a good game for you.
However there r few things in this game is pointless, especially the cooking mastery.

I choose to master that at first but after spending so many time farming and cooking, when i first make the first recipe, Apple Pie, i was kinda excited but until i found out that this bloody pie doesnt stack.
U only have 24 inventory slots and every apple pie u made it need to consume 1 slot, and now im making chicken soup and no one in my guild is eating it until i told them too.

Lockpicking and armor is too OP, the defense system is too poor, our base always get raided IN FRONT OF OUR EYES.
They just came in with bloody end game armor, pick ur lock, get red, towers shoot them for 6-10HP, at the mean time they lockpick our towers and steal the arrows so the tower won't shoot them. and we r doomed.

We cant defend it, they have weapon which kills u in one hit, all u can do is watching them messing with ur base which u spent hours/days to build it, killed ur animals, all table furnaces and farms been destroyed while u r still a ghost. They dont response to u even u beg them for not raiding u or $hits, coz most of them r Taiwanese and Koreans. So they dont speak english.

Oh yeah and 1 more thing, I dont get this. This is Asia server and developer is from Korea, I dont understand why is it so laggy, every action u do will be delayed a sec. This is booshit.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since tree of life has evolved a fair bit i decided to redo my review, so here it goes :)

1. good skill system

2. great crafting gear

3. make new clothes at a table :P

4. easy to feed urself if ya have the stomach for it XD

5. good vibes all around, best played with friends :)

i have played this game for a while now and with everything that has happened so far i can honestly say, i have enjoyed every minute.

from crafting to hunting even salvageing the odd bit here and there this game has been a blast.

i made some friends and traveled the map

i set up shop and made some good coin :P

i even made my own little garden :D

only a few things that you can do but there is a fair bit more to do, with new crafting gear and a whole new look this game just keeps getting better.

this game does just what i need it to anyway, i play a nomad style merchant of sorts and that is how i built myself.



i may redo or simply edit the review if anything big happens with the skills or i find something big, thanks for reading :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very ambitious take on the Survival MMO genre which is overly saturated these days, this game does alot of things right and will one day be complete (hopefully).

Unlike most of the games in this genre (Rust/DayZ/H1Z1 etc) this game has a huge focus on crafting and building and also has a nice crime system in place. On death in this game what you lose is dependent upon your crime level, so getting killed while being peaceful doesnt mean as much of a setback as opposed to getting killed while a high level criminal.

The map is very large and has many different climates and terrains, with an update looming that will expand that further and also reset the map to a degree.

I recommend this game to anyone that loves this genre and also can handle bugs/wipes as this game is still very much Early Access.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

29th June 2015

Having been playing the tree of life for over 250 hours, i am going to tell you what is the story in the game honestly.

Once fall of the game has been starting, few of broadcasting in the twitch. There is lots land available now for the settlement of newborns and the monsters' sieges are weaker than before. The cases of gangsters' raids are less than before as too many players quitted, now, the island is popular with the killers. Although the crime system is introducted, it is really useless for the safe of newborns and even skilled players. Why?

The killers are going to seek more victims, do more burglaries and even demolishment, as their crime score is reached the peak. Few of players can challenge the killers who armed with the top level weapons and armors and living in strongholds, so the killers do not care about the penalty. That is why newborns are no chance to do self-defence or revenge. Also, most locks in the game are crap, the killers with top level lockpicking can open most locks easly like taking a pee in their home.

In conclusion, no place is safe for newborns even staying in their sweet home. I hope my report can help people know much about the recent of the game.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

12th June 2015

No matter how you love the tree of life, your sweet home is attacked by sustained monsters' siege day by day and even  gangsters' raids with notorious massacres and fulled of insulting jokes. Being frustrated, that's why so many newborns have quited the game gradually since last week and no more new broadcasting in the twitch.

The game is playable, but only for the offspring of The Viking or The Hun now,  they can do what their ancestry felt free to do a challenge to the civilization. Actually, the game title should be :

Tree of Life: Beginng of a Raid/ being raided"

Why i am so impressed? I saw a large raid in a channel of twitch last night. Not only a village is ruined but also the dream of the villagers who have played the game for over a week.

I do not recommend the game "NOW". Let us see what will happen in the beta version."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game

This game is a lot of fun. A small grind but not too terribly bad as you do not want to get max level overnight since no real things to do at max level are in place as of yet.

You get to build your village and craft and explore different atmospheres. Run around to find areas where certain materials to craft with spawn. Meet interesting people and make trades, work together and have community. The music is straight out of castleville and so are the graphics, but if you are looking for a game that is amusing this is it.

Note all the reviews before 6/18 that are negative, they are people complaining about everything getting destroyed by pvpers and griefers. The devs listened to the players and did something about that. Now you will notice all of the huehue's and pvpers are crying and thumbs down. However please note how VERY SMALL portion of the reviews this is, only a handful compared to hundreds. These people got what they deserved, this is now a much better game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The core idea and gameplay of the game is great and I am excited to see this game grow and improve throughout time. I did not expect myself to be even interested in playing this game, but after around two hours, I started to enjoy it.

PROS:

~The core concept and overall gameplay of the game - Playing with friends I feel is what makes the game, however, your views may differ if you're just playing it by yourself.

~Crafting is interesting and develops very well as your skills level (there are tons of skills in this game that improve over time)

~The game world is huge and dynamic - this allows for you and your friends to find the perfect spot to gather materials and build up your town and trading posts and thrive within your group/guild. Word will spread of those who come around and destroy villages which then emphasises more teamwork to bolster your defenses to prevent destruction to all your hard work.

CONS: (This game is obviously in early access, but I feel I should point out some cons that I have noticed)

~Very unoptimized - I get an average of 22-29 fps in this game (with my 4.0GHz i7 4790, and GTX 970 @ 1504MHz  on core clock)

~Graphics aren't the greatest - this could be an issue to some, but I have faith that the game will improve greatly while still mainting the art style that is trying to be achieved.

If you and your friends are looking for a good group-oriented game to play, I would highly recommend it. I hope to see the developers continue to improve this game as it has a lot of potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Here is my early review of this sandbox MMO.
Tree of Life is:
A game with a steep learning curve.
An addictive MMO, like any sandbox.
Full of bad translations to English.
A game I wouldn't play alone, even though there are many players online at various moments of the day.
A world where the true enemies (well, at least, for beginners) are the environment and the monsters.
Full of mysteries. The items always have a mysterious description, sometimes really vague.
A game with deep" character development. You get better at what you do
date:
the game increases your attributes relatively to which skills you use the most.
A game without voice chat but with functional text-based normal chat.
A relatively good Early Access game.
This game took me a lot of time to understand before I could do anything complex. I searched for about one hour for wheat until my friend found some after we gave up on finding any.

Good game overall."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A good sandbox, that offers great opportunities for social interaction and different activities ( you can be a ruler of a small town or fortress in the desert, or be a mercenary, who helps with the defence for some money or resources... or even a trader ) and it's only up to you.

Take into consideration, this game isn't for single player, you have to communicate to achieve something. Plus, this game is about craft and discovering.

I'm really eager to have some guild wars or participate in the defence of my own city.

In short, this game is very perspective and i hope a lot of new things and opportunities are waiting us in future, and even now it's nice to spend some time in it with some friends.

( btw, you'll need few trustworthy comrades, if you want to be safe from bandits and killers, because there is full pvp with its penalties. I have already met some guys with red nicknames, uttering battle cries and trying to kill people.. and failing miserably )

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Summary

Overall - Very Good, the game is very team/group focused which was a draw to us at SENSOU, the game has a lot of sand within the sandbox to play with even at this early access stage which is encouraging. The game naturally has bugs and things that need improving, the non skill progression of shields and 2h swords is a little frustrating. My biggest personal issue is the limitation to guild sizes, the effect this has on community's playing the game is massive.

Full review

Graphics - cartoonish by nature which will not be too everybodys taste, i personally have no issue with it and like the art design.

Performance - seems to be mixed from my experience, i have a decent pc however there is some delay or desync present where players or mobs pass with the fighting happening a number of meters away, overall its ok but there is clearly server issues.

Map - Certainly large enough to accommodate lots of players, the game has a decent mmo feel about it.

Features - Lots, i like the PvP mechanics, although it needs work, i like the crafting as well as the city building, there is plenty to do, the skill progression is decent levelling via use is also good.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game gave me the feeling back i had in my first Minecraft-Hours. Its really enjoyable (when they fix the invisible-mob bug) and and shows, that you dont need the fanciest of all graphics to have awesome game.

From what i can say atm its a well combination out of Rust/Minecraft/Archeage and combines the chill of developing your character and raiding bases. In addition there is plenty late-game content in the varied areas which im looking forward to visit later.

If the developers stay focused on fixes and improvements and listen to the feedback from the players, this game has a lot of potential. Im surprised by myself how hyped i am on this game, just after i got to know it a few hours ago.

I really recommend to buy this game in a 4pack with some friends, because its definitely is a game what you want to play with your buddies. The fact that you cant max all skills forces" you into teamplay and its an awesome feeling to build your town with your mates when everybody has some specific tasks and professions."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros: Game requires teamwork to get anything done in a respectable amount of time. This reduces the KoS mentality of most survival games I've seen. This is a pretty big plus imo. First game I've seen where large groups of people will just come together and start helping with very few people trying to grief.

Cons: I can definitely see groups closing doors to outsiders very fast if Guild player limits aren't increased. Solo play is possible at the lowest level but the limit of skill points used will probably rear its ugly head for high tier crafting for solo players. Griefing and the lack of punishment is a very big issue right now. Someone ransacking your goods? Too bad! If you kill him you go red name. He drops 1 piece of loot as punishment while you run around for 2 hours as a KoS target to strangers. It's especially bad if you have good gear you don't want to lose.

TLDR: Game is alpha and the latest patch on day 3 release is definitely a good sign. But $20 is just too steep for this game in its current state. If you have $20 to burn, I would Definitely Recommend it. For everyone else, wait until the game is in a balanced state.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been playing the game with a few friends for the past several hours(Steam tallies 6). It's good fun, rather rough around the edges, but I think it was worth the fifteen bucks we spent on it(we sprung for that four pack, you see).

By rough, I mean that with the game basically just having come out, figuring out how to do anything is kind of difficult, and there's not much of a way to ask. Mostly I just gathered stuff and ran around shanking things with bone daggers while my friends did most of the crafting stuff. Combat is kind of clunky with how the game sometimes doesn't lock you on to enemies, letting them get in several cheapshots while you dance around him trying to get the game to lock on, and the enemies rather annoyingly circle-strafe you which, as I said, is just annoying and doesn't add any real difficulty to anything. Some materials seem kind of hard to come by; tin has been a recurring issue since for some reason instead of having rocks containing tin you can only find the stuff from the corpses of dead sailors(which are faaaaairly rare, I guess). The night is pitch black, which while realistic, is frustrating because you can often get jumped by enemies and have no clue what's going on, and you can't have a torch in your hand with a weapon, so you end up fighting blind at night. On top of that, light sources(namely bonfires) are hard to maintain through the night and don't put off all that much light anyways, making them kind of useless. A few times enemies have attacked us that didn't actually appear on other player's screens, which is mind-boggling. There's several other niggling little details, but at that point I'd just be nitpicking.

Now, it should be reiterated that we've only played the game for six hours; some of this might just be my inexperience speaking, but the whole package is rather unpolished in a number of ways. Expected? Sure, this is an early access game. But hey, if I don't list the problems I've had they won't get fixed, right? On the whole, though, I DID enjoy my time with the game so far, and will likely play the game more in days to come, and wholeheartedly look forward to what they'll do with the thing in the future. I'd say pick it up now and play it. S'only 20 bucks, and if you get three friends to pitch in for the 4-pack it's only 15. Not a bad price for what's already here, I'd say.

In summation: Yeah, I recommend the game. :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For an Alpha game, this one is actually pretty good.  It has it's share of problems but it's in the works and I'm sure they will eventually be smoothed out.

The crafting system is pretty in depth, there's lots of stuff to craft, lots of material farming.  Could use better organization, though, and the lack of actual housing is kind of offputting if you're used to playing voxel based games with a bit more freedom for creating.  Game is about impossible to play at night.  You can't see anything and lights do little to remedy this.  It's just unrealistically dark and the days go by far too quickly to get much done so you're pretty much required to sit and do nothing on several occasions.

This is not a bad game and is showing a lot of potential, I mainly write out this review in hopes that it might be seen by the developers and perhaps look into some of the issues the game currently has and tweak them a bit.  I'll definitely be staying to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is pretty fun, but grindy.
Improving skills increases your stats as well and stat increases are very visible, making the grind feel worth it.
Playing with a bunch of random people makes it fun, as you work together and build a settlement.

I have a few issues that I'd like to be addressed though.
Crafting is a bit iffy as recipes are only visible at certain levels, but recipes themselves already have crafting level requirements. I'd prefer if it all recipes were visible and had crafting level requirements.
Crafting also results in various quality of items: which makes items unstackable. So I can make five bandages, but unable to stack, so I have to use five slots to use them quickly. I'm not sure how to address this however.
The nature of the game allows players to take each other stuff, such as farming plots or cooked food. A security method for a structure that a player builds should be allowed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So...Tree of Life...The game is fun, addictive in it's simplicity and thoroughly enjoyable working with a group of folks to build up a town and make neat things/live a life. However, the game is overflowing with what you would expect in an open sandbox game, griefers, thieves. Whatever you want to call them, they will stomp all over anything you are working on, with the game giving little to no opportunities as it is to protect yourself. Enjoy watching that livestock you painstakingly gathered get slaughtered by someone who was bored. Enjoy watching all your days materials get stolen overnight by a group of folks who trashed all your storage while you were asleep. That's pretty much what you can expect from the game as is. It's truly unfortunate because there is a lot to love underneath all that grime. I'll never understand why people do this kind of thing in these games, because all it does is drive off everyone else who could help breathe some life into the world, but it is what it is.

Pros:
+Gameplay is solid
+Enjoyable RPG elements to professions
+Lot of fun to see teamwork pay off
+Combat works relatively well

Cons:
-Need at least 10 people to make a functional town. Small groups will suffer from griefers and material grind.
-Current system punishes indiscriminately, meaning you can't kill a thief without becoming a criminal yourself.
-Locks, Towers and other measures to defend your town do not work yet (mostly just don't work WELL enough).
-Overflowing with griefers.

Final Verdict: The game itself is great fun with friends, ruined by a particular subset of players. Stay away unless that is what you are into. As it is the game is a firm thumbs down until the devs improve systems to allow players who want to focus on town building an ability to survive.

Update with patch notes: So they just released a patch today that adds thief criminal status and makes it easier to get defenses up around the town. It does not fix everything that I listed in my review, however, it does show that they are taking steps in the right direction to address common issues players may face. I will say this, even with all the negative stuff I put in about the game, I still am playing it. So take that for what you will, you will deal with the negative element in the game, but the gameplay is worthwhile if you're okay with that. Changing my review to a thumbs up with the devs doing exactly what needed to be done to fix the game, good on you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game really has been a nice little surprise. I was looking to buy another game when I decided to check out the last few months of smaller releases, along with hearing from a few people that the game was the most fun they have had in an online rpg since Ultima Online (which is sitll to this day, my fav mmo by a long shot).

This has a very good community from the 10-11 hours I have played of it so far, fun gameplay and is in pretty good shape for an Early Access game. Sort of a mix between Ultima Online, DayZ, 7 days to die, Minecraft and a bunch of its own aspects. Can't wait to see what is added to this game in the future but so far it is very very very enjoyable and so far more worth the money than Ark has been.

The graphics might not be that good and might throw some people off, but give it a try or check out some videos and youll see it really is a game to keep an eye out on. There are some bugs to as to be expected with EA games, but to be honest I am pretty surprised at the level of the game this early on. Want to go back to the days when you built villages/cities with your build members and had to defend it and your teammates no matter the cost? Everything is player made, there is fighting or crafting to specialize in to when you join a guild. Grab a friend or two and give this game a go! So far, it is very good!

When I first saw a few screenshots I thought Ultima Online? What?". But now having played it I can see why some people mention UO. Teamwork is rewarded
date: the guild aspect is already well implimented (even early on) and its just a blast to play. Also pretty stable and decently optimized for an early version of the game. See you all in the gameworld and don't hesitate to msg me for the coordinates for the guild village I am in.\n\nNice little game that flew under the radar for me and I am sure many others
recommended: if you want an enjoyable online rpg that doesn't hold your hand and has aspects of mmos of yester year

Early Access Review

The game is in early access. With that said there have been a lot of people bashing on the devs for some of the things they have both added and tooken away form this game. In my opinion the game is pretty solid and can only get better. It really focuses toword the PvE side of things and at the moment !strongly! goes against most forms of PvP such as stealing, griefing, random killing, etc.. etc.. While I for one enjoy the PvE side of things, I do at the same time feel for those who do come to play the game for its PvP potenital. Given time, I am sure a system would be put into place so that guilds could go to war with one another. With that said, the game is extremely PvE friendly, and leans toword getting people to work together to form a community of crafters, farmers, gathers, soldiers, etc.. I for one would love to see a good mix of PvE and PvP in the game. Both help to keep things interesting but finding a balance to help keep players on both sides happy could be fairly difficult with the current checks and balances.

All in all, the game is fun and enjoyable. It will keep you busy for hours as you and your friends build, explore, fight, and grow along with many other players.

8/10 Keep up the good work devs.
