reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far it seems to be a good game. Has the basic elements of crafting that make a sandbox-esque game enjoyable. I like that people are able to work together to build things, and there are cool little things like the immersive, roleplay style chat system where when you're incapacitated/turned into a ghost from dying, you get garbled text output.

Things I don't like, that I expect are relatively easy to change or improve--

The hit boxes for combat are awful. If I end up fighting an enemy that moves even a little bit, suddenly i'm no longer focused and my attacks don't connect at all, which is not something I think has any place in an open-world 3d fighting setup. Swinging a weapon should check the hit boxes in general, not whether you're focused on them. I get killed by weak enemies due to this.

The character animations could use some improvement, as of now they remind me of n64 duke nukem style animations.

Entering crafting menus and any kind of storage units are, like the aforementioned hit boxes, really 'stiff', they aren't very easy to access. The right click and drag is neat, as it allows you to cancel your menu with mouseup, but I think in order for it to be smooth and enjoyable its better to adjust the camera so that in third person you treat things like it. At the moment it treats it as if my character needs to look at it, so theres this awkward way I have to offset it to get proper focus onto a target.

Since this is a new game I'm hoping the devs stay on it and continue to improve it. Me and my relatively large group of friends will all likely be long-time players if they continue to add content and polish the game. If I have any suggestion besides the things above, its to make sure to add 'content'. By that, I mean plenty of neat new items and such to check out. Plenty of neat variations in the world, like biomes. I also like to decorate quite a bit, so please don't skip out on the items that don't have a practical use besides looking nice or creating a setting =)

Good job on getting it this far, I look forward to seeing it improve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've definitely lost a few hours playing this for only the last couple of days. I am enjoying my time by finding a group of people who were willing to let me join them. The game is okay to play alone but there are some aspects you're going to want a group for.

If you build something, make sure you break it down and put it into your inventory when you log off. This game suffers the big thing that most games suffer from, the community. If you're trying to play alone, I can guarantee someone is going to come by and destroy or steal just about everything you have. The good thing though is that unlike most of these other survival games around, when you log off, people can't kill your sleeping body and take your inventory and housing stays broken for quite a long time so if someone breaks your house, you can easily log on the next day, break it down and get your loot.

Your character will not have enough points to distribute into every skill of the game, which is fine but limits solo play if that's what you're looking for. It seems best to take up 1-2 weapon skills and the rest be put into crafting of some kind. You're going to have to rely on a guild if you want a good defensible land, good armor, weapons and items.

The mobs/monsters will break your defenses down really quickly and don't even think about fighting anything when you first start out. Except rats and livestock, you're good there. It's hard enough to keep a couple of people on at all times to have to worry about players but the mobs can just let them inside of your fort within a couple of minutes. I haven't gotten to stone walls yet, just the wooden ones so I'm assuming that will help with this issue.

The game controls very easily, it's easy to learn and it is pretty easy so far as I have found to find a group of people who will be willing to run around with as long as you pull your own weight. Even if you were to be wiped out, it's easy enough to build your stock back up with a couple of hours of gameplay.

All in all. I would suggest getting this game. It's easy to play, there is plenty to do and there will only be more content added at this point and mostly, it's fun. Just get some friends if you plan on playing heavily.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is a lighthearted survival game. It challenges the player to either make trustworthy friends to cooperate with, or go it alone with all the dangers of having no one to watch your back. Yes, there are raiders; some demand tribute, some just want anything not tied down to the ground, and some kill and destroy for fun -- but it doesn't rule your experience. You can store, lock up things, and repair easily. On the whole, if you're willing to be friendly and interact, life will reward you with the little awesome things that can happen between players.

As for PvE, there's an autotargeting system (the green outline) that lets you lock on, which is especially helpful for hitting monsters that look like they're running all over the place - or sheep who won't stay still! Gathering food, leathers, straps, ore, etc. is all exciting for me in particular because I get to have my home base, but am encouraged to travel the continent for different items I need. This spurs interactions, sometimes some stiff situations I have to talk myself out of. Sometimes I meet a nice person building a campfire and I stop to chat. The mapping of resources keeps players circulating.

This game is in Alpha. The developers are doing their best to find a nice balance for players from both walks of life: PvE and PvP. They read the discussion boards and suggestions and try to implement/try new things to see if they can please the farmers, the grinders, the tree choppers, and the raiders.

I don't suggest you play it if you're easily bothered by other players and their actions because things do happen. I highly suggest working with a friend, at least in the beginning while you're working to raise skills and such. I split the work with a friend and it made life WAY easier - as far as I could read from other peoples' comments and complaints.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been playing this game for a month now.  I started playing this game with some friends.  Our guild camp has been fortunate enough to survive so far but I can't say the same for our neighboring guilds.  We've seen atleast 8 different guilds that started playing around the same time we did and end up quitting as soon as they're base got griefed or destoryed by bully guilds (Mainly some guild called Ironborn).  The entire map is filled with abandoned camps.  Mostly noob camps that ended up quitting after getting griefed.  There are so many abandoned camps it is very difficult to find a large enough open spot to build camp.

This game is fun as long as you either play with a large group of friends or you can join a large established guild.  Otherwise, you're just sitting duck basically collecting mats for the big guilds to steal and/or destroy.  It's not a possibility, it's a guarantee.  This game seems to be filled with bullies who enjoy destroying peoples work, just to do it even though there is no benefit whatsoever.

The game has lots of serious flaws.  When I first started playing I caught several people stealing or killing my animals on my property.  When I attack that person, I'm the one who is awarded a criminal record.  Speaking of criminal records.  When I mentioned that there are no real consequences for griefing, bullying, stealing or destorying other peoples property, criminal records do not last long at all.  Criminal Record debuffs last between 30 seconds to a few hours depending on the severity of the crime.  I dont know why they called it Criminal Record because your crimes are not recorded.  After the debuff wears off, there are no records of any crimes you committed.

Overall, I can't recommend this game.  This is a sandbox game but you are very limited on how or what you build due to available open space or having your buildings destroyed by bullies.  It doesn't hurt that the map is not very big and there are too many abandoned camps.  If you're thinking of purchasing this game, all you have to do is go on their Community Hub Discussions and you'll see what kind of people play this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is another attempt on making a multiplayer sandbox survival game, and unlike some other recent releases, this is quite successful on a glimpse, at least from most of the reviews.

GRAPHICS:
The art style is cartoonish, which may not suit everyone.  I am okay with this so far since I am not focusing too much on the graphics, but there are definitely lots of room for improvement, e.g. the low polygon modeling of structures, awkward animations etc.

GAMEPLAY:
As with all you would expect from a survival game, you punch trees, you make tools, and you build houses. The gameplay is solid, yet the complexity of the system makes it hard to grasp from the start. The skill point system reminds me of Ultima Online, which seems to be a popular trend in all the new multiplayer sandbox games (I am looking at you, Life is Feudal). You grind items to level up your skills, which unlocks more items you can grind to level up more skills.

The items you can craft are not shown until you reaches certain skill level, which is sometimes confusing when you are not leveling all skills and you don't know how to craft certain materials from the certain skill while leveling a different skill. This is where the multiplayer part come in - you can have different people leveling different skills and helping each other out.

The UI is clean and functional, though sometimes irresponsive. The control is classic WASD with F to pickup items on the ground. However, the game does not have a keybind remapping option nor does it shows which key does what, so you may need to try all the keys on your keyboard to see what they do.

COMMUNITY:
I am playing on the Asia server. The community seems indifferent, most people do not respond. Trolls and thieves are common in game, but that is part of the gameplay. It is hard to survive on your own, so grab some buddies to accompany you on your journey and remember - lock everything you can. It is up to you to protect yourself.


Since it is still early access, it is difficult to judge a game. I see potentials in this game, but whether or not it can grow into a mature multiplayer sandbox survival game depends on the developer's dedication. Nevertheless I am willing to support the game and hopefully it will turn out to be great at release.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is an engaging and fun sandbox game, the game is in early access, however the content and progression is paced enough that people are not finished within a day. The game has a strong focus on casual, relaxed game play with music that reinforces that point.

The early game is without a tutorial at the time of writing, but the game is easy and simple to pick up for most basic skills. Resource distribution for most resources is ideal; however ores are too rare for the difficulty in levelling mining up. Resources change based on the zone you are in, making a list of where to locate resources is really important for later in the game when you are missing, for example, braided straps.

The mid game is where the game is still being fleshed out, with some mechanics still unknown to the wider community, such as ranching. Defending your settlement is impossible without walls, and the player should focus on skilling and logging out with everything they want when they have had enough for the time being, either players will destroy settlements or the night time mobs will erase most abandoned settlements in short order (a very nice mechanic for getting rid of abandoned buildings). This mechanic allows the map to feel not so settled.

PvP in the game is a mixed bag, with the system in the early stages with no current claim system in place, the only way to protect your belongings is to group together so that there is constant activity in your town, or work on locks as quickly as possible and hope nobody thinks you are worth lockpicking.

All in all, for a freshly released game, it is enjoyable and engaging to play, combat can be intense and fun and updates that balance the game seem to be frequent, the developers react to elements of the game that may be too hard (a good example was iron ingots, which require 25 mining, were used in wooden gates, which put walls outside everyone‚Äôs capabilities to place, were nerfed to requiring just 10 sculptures)

Early Access Review

Pros:
-In-depth crafting
-Tons of things to do
-Fun with friends/active guild

Cons:
-Clunky controls
-Constant and annoying building maintenance
-Framerate issues (bounces 60 to 10 fps)
-Annoyingly short day/night cycle
-Limited storage*

*item stacks are very small. You also have to constantly build storage huts and having to protect them too.

It has a lot of potential for an early access game, but there is a LOT of things that needs to be worked on. It feels like a job more than a game, due to constant maintenance and a lot of grinding. If I was you, save your money unless you're into builder MMO's. It's an intresting game to own, but I'm not touching it until they have some sort of massive update.

6.5/10 this feels like a job, make it fun

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a new game, it has potential. The positive benefits of this game are well advertised, so I'll focus on the negatives that stand out immidiately to me.

1. Griefing

In it's current state, it is far too easy for people to loot all your goods you worked hard to get. Yes things can lock, but there seem to be traces of evil everywhere marking pillaged areas.

2. Day/Night cycle

Days seem way too short. Starting off in the game, I lose a lot of initial enjoyment because I barely have any daylight to go out and try to explore for items I need. I seem to spend a majority of my time trying to find food and then before I know it, it's dark again.  I guess I just need to choose to starve for awhile to get ahead in the game. Hopefully this is addressed later.

3. Hunger decay rate

Hunger seems to drop way too fast. This mixed with the  Day/Night cycles starts to create a cycle in the start of the game of doing nothing but hunting for food and then hiding from deadly enemies all night. Please at least reduce hunger decay by 1/4th of the rate or something to provide some relief.


All in all though, it is still enjoyable though frustrating. I have faith though that it will pull through and address these issues since the game is very brand new.


UPDATES:

1. Griefing

After spending more time in the game, I have some suggestions of how some of the key issues can be resolved. The biggest being that we as players need more ways to defend our land. Not to a ridiculous amount, but more than what is currently provided.

First, perhaps adding a new building type for Barracks" that could spawn NPC guards that would fight intruders. This helps to deter looting while we are away from the game.

Second
date: make it so that the arrow towers perhaps deal a little extra to players. It seems that well armoured players are barely affected even by the best arrows.\n\nThird is to nerf down lock picking. It is far too easy to lock pick in mine and others opinions. Perhaps make lockpicks only produce 5 instead of 10 at a time. Also
recommended: have different tiers of lockpicks for copper
hoursPlayed: iron
voteText: etc. Copper can pick the lower level locks
helpfulPercent: while iron is required for medium level locks
votesHelpful:
and mithril for the higher level locks.


2. Day/Night cycle

After spending more time in the game
votesTotal: the amount of time only seems very short when you are just starting and trying to learn to play the game. Would still like to see a small increase in the day time cycle
votesFunny:
but it is fair enough as is.

3. Hunger decay rate

I still say that the hunger decays way too quickly. It is nearly a requirement to always have good meat on you to stay well fed. I would be happy if the decay rate would change by even 10-15% of it's current rate. That way it still goes somewhat fast
commentsCount:
but not as fast as it is currently.

4. Durability (Repair)

This is a new one that is somewhat frustrating
column16: but not too much. I would like to see the ability to repair tools
column17: weapons
column18: armour
column19: etc. On the lesser scale of things
column20: it does not really matter too much when you are just using common items. But let us say that I just happen to make a Legendary weapon. Well
column21: it kinda sucks that you can never repair it. So once it runs out
column22:
it is out forever.


I will continue to update my review as I play and experience more things"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game full of action and possibilities, yet at the same time, one can feel the slow breath of the world and enjoy the sunrays warming your character's skin as you stand there fishing.
You can care for animals, like a real rancher in this game. Carry your lost sheep back home to their stable, cure the sick cows and gather some fresh eggs from the chicken.

The game offers a wide array of fun crafts, such as tinkering and carpentry, creating streetlights, messageboards, fancy torches to go around the pretty dark and scary nights, to steal some of your neighbours freshly baked applepies with your tinkering tools.

Ahh, finally a game that is not all about fighting and war!
There is more to this one. A calming and relaxing atmosphere, to hang out around the campfire with your guildies, and go shopping in your self-created town!

Of course there are also a bunch of weaponskills that can be mastered, to fight off some darker creatures of the night, together with your comrades. As well as scaenging some useful items from animals and goblins, ogres  and the lot.

It is still Early Access, so there is plenty of potential for the game makers to make something unique out of this. Something we haven't tasted before. Something beyond battling for territory like the thousand other strategy games. We can create a safehaven here, explore, trade with eachother, and experience life when it was still simpler: Gathering ingredients, crafting them and surviving from nature together.
From this, we can evolve, creating towns, cities, yes, even Empires!

And from this potential, we can maybe in the future even help NPC creatures build up their towns and cities too, solving their quests and aiding them as we discover the history of a unique, finally (almost)  non-violent world.

Come and escape the real life warzone to build up something peaceful with us!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now that I've dumped 30+ hours into this game, it's time for a review.

Let me start off by saying, I was REALLY hesitant to buy this game, and read lots of reviews before I did so.  I've played a lot of survival ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•mes like this, and a lot of them turn out to be unfinished abandoned garbage, but some do turn out great.

Keep in mind this game is in Early Access so this review may not be accurate at a later point in time, and they may have fixed more of it by then.


PROS:

-Fun to play with friends or just make friends online and play with them.
-TONS of skills to level up, and you can combine them any way you want.  You want to be a master of Unarmed Combat whilst also being a Fisherman that's buff as ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• from Logging?  Do ittttt.
-Tons of time can be put into this game, if you're really looking to go ham in the play-time.
-Lots of items and gear and loot to find/upgrade.
-The devs are really good about fixing bugs within the first couple days of people reporting them, as far as I've seen.

CONS:

-The biggest con for me is this:  The devs announced EVERYWHERE that they were making the map 4x+ bigger than it previously was (I had not played the game previous to this 4x update), however what they actually did was make it 4x bigger and block off 3/4 the new map with impenetrable fog, so you can't go to those areas anymore.  They claim it's for development purposes, but that seems kind of 'swindly' to me.  Don't promise one thing and then give another.
-Combat is boring.  Point and Click pretty much.
-If you don't have friends to play with, or aren't willing to play with people in the game, you probably won't progress very far unless you spend hours and hours grinding materials.
-Lots of bugs, duh.

OVERALL:

It's really not a bad game, it just needs a lot of work done on it.  I've enjoyed it so far, made some friends, dumped 30+ hours into something I only spent $13.99 on, so I consider it worth it.  Do I recommend it?  Only if you're willing to wait for more content to be released and if you're a somewhat social gamer.  IMO this game would be real hard to play solo and make any real progress.

Rating: 7/10 (mostly for broken promises)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have currency to speak here, with currently almost 1900 hours of beta play/testing now in this game.

After giving this game more time, I have changed my review from negative to positive.
(Very positive)

The developers got on top of this game's game-breaking bugs rather quickly, although it was only after losing the vast majority of it's players. And also after I had already given the game a negative review.

This is a wordy review, but this game deserves every word here, and more...

Very fun and challenging game, the development team has great ideas for the future, no other games that I've experienced has so many survival, city-building, crafting, PVE and PVP balance like this game does.

Do not let the acronym: PVP scare some of you away, there is a criminal system in the game that creates an environment that proves to be very costly to players who will harass, assault, wound, kill or damage the property of other players.
...And likewise, do not let the words criminal system" scare some of you PVP'ers away either. The criminal sytem is implemented well
date: very well.\nI myself play with a rather large criminal penalty looming over my head once or twice every week. and have only found it slightly inconvient one time so far.\nBut
recommended: I do not go about grieving other players either. Grieving other players is why the crinminal system was implemented into the game to begin with.\nIf you want to play a bad guy or a sneak in  this game
hoursPlayed:
then be prepared to spend a lot of time 'safely' hiddem from other players while your criminal penalty times out.

I am not just blowing hot air here now: There really is not enough space in this review to expound on all of the brilliant features that are all integrated together to make this an extremely fun and even exciting game to play.
The quality and range of end-goal and play-style pursuits that players have in this game seems endless already

very very different)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tricked by an early access game. It still needs a ton of work.

-The combat system is totally stupid. I became a criminal for attacking someone who was stealing from my house. Then his friends showed up and killed me, all the while they stayed good" and I was the criminal and lost everything. And my auto-defense towers didn't even shoot.

-The targeting is a joke and completely not scalable for an MMO with large number of combatants.

-Defenses are absolutely worthless; you can punch down a wall within 3 minutes by yourself and without a weapon. Stone walls take about 10 minutes. Yet take a very very long time to build.

-There is no way to lock in your mounts or animals in a stable or barn so they are easily and constantly killed or stolen.

-Hunger - You will always be hungry. The bar drops so fast you can only forge for food most of the time. Its the worst part of this game.

-Day/Night Cycle - Days are much too short and the nights are much too long. And Zombies will come and destroy everything to made since they auto attack everything. I just love waking up in the morning to find my entire village destroyed by NPCs.

On the plus side
date: the map is huge and concept is great

Early Access Review

I've played a lot of Survival Games such as Rust, Dayz, and more of those type of games on steam, but no matter what, you always end up dead and frustrated after a few hours of sessions alone. So far from the 3 hours ive been playing, most of all people i've encountered are friendly and informative. It seems that teamwork in this game is valued despite only meeting up strangers and bonding. There may be some PK's, but the game punishes those who kill but having them a criminal status, and drops all their loot when they die. Harvestmoon is my favorite game of all time, and this game lets me experience that in a coop which made my purchase worth it.

Pros
Team-based Building
A lot of things to do
Atmosphere is refreshing
Soundtrack is nice

Cons
Graphics may be outdated
Fighting is a bit weird
Has a few bugs


Overrall: The game is quite nice, if you want to play a survival game in a different atmosphere. I definitely recommend it. Sorry for english, as I am not a native speaker.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Beta Review ~ Tree of Life

Well as a outside originally looking in I had my curiosities about the game. The artwork and the original game play looked like it was a little too much to be true for such a beta game. I have been through a few that are just not worth the money.

That being said, I bought the game May 28 and already logged over 10 hours into the game.

Let's start with the bad even though there is very little currently.
- 1 - Low Content
Right now the game has a lot of content to muddle through, however it seems like so much more is planned for this game and I can not wait to see what they reveal in the coming years.

- 2 - Minor Bugs
Even though this is in all Beta games. It still is to be expected that some bugs exist however, all that the group and I found were map issues and maybe the typical lag here and there but these are quickly being taken care of by the Dev team.

- 3 - Kill o Sight
We all know it, but for those that do not. Starting areas are already seemingly camped by people who wish to bring nothing but a discontenting game play. Open Player Killing is a very real thing is this game though get yourself in a group of friends and you might just find yourself taking it to these Criminals" of the game. There is a deterrent to this playstyle however
date: that if a player does kill another
recommended: they are tagged at "Criminals" and instead of a random item dropping from the inventory
hoursPlayed: the entire bag drops including equips. However
voteText:
this does create others wanting to provoke an innocent to attack so that they can kill them.

- 4 - More If/When they Come

Now for a brick listing for the game of its Pros.
- 1 - Enriched Environment
Tree of Life hits you right off the bat with stunning Environmental beauty as you end up as a Shipwrecked individual on one several parts of this world. The sunsets and sunrises are nothing to scoff at. So far the only weather we have seen are clear and sunny skies though I am sure weather such as rain or cloudy will eventually come into play.
The landscape is very enriched with Forests
helpfulPercent: Deserts
votesHelpful: Badlands
votesTotal: Plains
votesFunny: and Tundras. The game even varies in MULTIPLE altitudes throughout the lands. Even the Tree of life itself is in the map for you to view in awe of. Be warned though
commentsCount:
the land is not with out its dangers.

- 2 - Growing World
Tree of Life is a sandbox world that grows as the players do. Feel like wanting to build a Fort? Well the wilds will take notice and Challenge you. Want to live as a nomad? Grind skills and walk the world selling wears. Live a life you want in the way you want
column16:
though every change you make effects the world in which we all live in.

- 3 - Indepth Skilling System
Tree of Life has a Skill system in which the more you use the better you get with that skill
column17: however you are limited to the number of skill points. However
column18:
don't let this think you will make a mistake in leveling a skill. If you find you want to specialize later you can tell the system to pull points from other skills to max the ones you want. You can even lock skills so they do not grow at all when you use them.

- 4 - Community Driven
This follows my previous point. Because you are only given so much to Specialize in
column19: you will end up having to rely on others to fill in the gaps
column20: which will see many strangers making deals to help one another out. Though
column21: beware
column22:
you never know what another player's intentions are except for the Red named "Criminals".

- 5 - Sandbox
This is a Cry to the world to let them know that the game's title does not lie. Build everywhere
column23: very very limited were you can NOT build. Build massive forts
column24: or build a small town. Live the life of a nomad
column25:
or as a Soldier defending the weak. Be and build what your heart desires. With so much planned how could you go wrong.


Now keep in mind this is an Early Access review but so much is good about this game already. Worth the 20$ and even some just for the extra unlocks. These by the way are in no way game breaking. Stop on by and join us in this wonderful world of "Tree of Life"."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is ridiculously fun, especially one that just recently launched its Early Access. I've read some reviews where they state that its grindy.  I don't know if its because I've played Life is Feudal (so much grind, it makes you want to melt your face off), but this isn't grindy at all (to me). You build stuff. You jack cows and chickens from the wild. You get beat up by stupidly strong skeletons/trolls/plants (yes plants)/wolves/other things. You beat said things up. You (can) beat up other players. You (can) cooperate with other players. One thing it lacks is the ability to actually party up. So if you go exploring with your pals, you can lose each other pretty easily and not have any map indicator to find them. However, there is a large, detailed map which helps negate that problem to a degree. Plenty of things can be added but it has so much potential! Will be playing this often. I tend to get so into I lose track of time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am REALLY enjoying this game. It is already very playable, especially for an early access game.
My impression of it is that it's a combination of Ultima Online, Minecraft and Harvest Moon.
The skill system is very much like Ultima Online, you can work up several skills, but only have so many points allowed, so you have to be a bit choosy on what you want to really have.
The karma system of getting flagged with more and more negative karma is very much like the earlier days of Ultima online. Yes, people can take advantage of being positive karma and grief others in ways that don't cause them negative karma, and  you will earn negative karma if you choose to take action against them in the form of killing the griefer. Frustrating, but not the end of the world in my own opinion.
The gui setup feels very similar to minecraft, along with the sandbox, find your own thing to do" feeling and the more agressive local monsters spawning at night. The crafting is at least similar enough to minecraft style crafting
date: but with the ease of recipes showing what you need instead of having to look it up online or remember.\nThe cutesy-ness is so harvest moon
recommended: along with the cows and pigs etc... being able to feed them and get milk and things from them. Then you can apparently give them potions to produce baby animals. The farming is pretty easy to do with reasonable time waiting for crops.\nFinally
hoursPlayed: so far for myself and husband who are playing
voteText: the social aspect is pretty interesting. it does remind me of the days when I played UO because there is no whispering or sending tells to people afar. You can hear people within normal hearing range of your character. Word bubbles appear above people's heads but there is also a chat log for some ease of looking back. We met with some other new players and are forming a sizable guild village
helpfulPercent: people are working together and that has been soooo cool. It does feel like the amount of work involved in building up a safe fortress
votesHelpful: you couldn't really pull that off alone. I don't always like social games
votesTotal: but this one has just really pulled me in. It's almost my perfect dream game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really fun. BUT, it was made by a single developer who doesnt speak very good english. Translations are bad, and theres some gameplay elements that need polishing. But all in all, Ive found alot of enjoyment in this game.
The community is overwhelmingly cool.

People band together and create villages with strangers, and unite to protect agains pvp raiders. the Pvp system is better than most survival games of this caliber, but it could still use polishing,
Sometimes youll be trolled by higher level characters. Theyll kill your cattle, break your buildings, and smash your gate....
BUT, buildings cant be completely destroyed, players cant steal everything, and resources are everywhere. Your stats persist, and your character development stays the same.
At this point, stats arent really functioning, some are missing, Im hoping this game developer pulls through and updates regularly, but, as long as he keeps the servers operational, this game is highly enjoyable for $20

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review based on early access.

Tree of Life is one of many survival games out there with the exception that it throws in heavy RPG elements with an MMO setting.

To proceed to unlock" new recipes you have to level up a corresponding skill by using a relevant skill. I.E. cutting wood to level up logging. This can lead to tedious grinding in some areas if you are working alone to progress a base.

The map is huge (literally took me an hour to cover 1/10th of the map going south) however it feels very cluttered. Its hard not to run into someone that has set up a small camp that is rotting away unused.

The graphics are a bit dated but it feels right in this environment leading to a relaxed setting and pleasing to the eyes.

TLDR run down.

Worth it if you like an easy flowing Crafting game based on MMO "skill" progression.
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is completely 100% unforgiving to new players. You start with nothing, already missing some hp, and every single enemy in the game can completely ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you. The first, and only weapon you are allowed to build at first, is incapable of even coming close to killing something, and the only way to get strong enough to kill something is to kill something. Logic.

On top of that, while you are desperately floundering around trying to figure out how the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to progress with crafting, every single time you die, you become a ghost for 3 minutes, incapable of talking, interacting, (the first thing you type comes out fine, which is good for scaring the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of people because they can't see your ghost body, but then the rest is all ..." automatically [Same when you are dead]) or doing anything else. The only way to shorten the respawn time from 3 minutes is to collect soul crystals while you are dead
date:
but the stupid crystals are spread out so far from eachother that it could literally be the entire 3 minutes before you find one and they only shorten the timer by 30 seconds when you do.

Now lets talk about how my "Journey" started.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
- I spawn
- Pitched black outside ( and I mean black
recommended:
darker than dead night in ARK: Survival Evolved)
- Wonder around for a second
- Get cracked by a red name

- Scared the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of someone by saying something while I'm a ghost (just once as mentioned earlier)
- I spawn again
- Start chopping a tree
- A yellow name comes up to me and starts hitting me

- Alt + F4

I didn't experience these unfortunate events because of some bad luck or because I'm an incompetent gamer.

The only "Tutorials" are guides written by the steam community which still aren't tutorials but instead tips on how to progress. None of which show the controls. reviewText:
Early Access Review

-- Not Disappointed with Purchase --

However, with that said I would like to add I just wish that purchase had occurred 6 months to a year in the future. I enjoy the concept of the game, the general helpfulness of the community in game. Yes, that's right not much kill on sight happening in a survival game. Sadly, I would absolutely not recommend buying this game at this point in time. Trust me in about a year this game will be something to look at.

CONS
- Enemy Spawning in camp.- That's right, after you've invested many hours gathering resources and building walls miracle zombies will spawn directly inside your camp and sit there destroying it (even while you are offline). This leads to mostly the first 2-3 hours upon logging in, rebuilding the destruction, further decreasing your ability to progress.

-Theiving with no criminal status- Currently in game you can hop a wall (or easily enter through a broken destroyed by a zombie) of a great empire and proceed to plunder their farms, kill their cattle, steel their vegetables, carts, mounts. All without any affect from the criminal system. I'm sure this will be addressed at a later date, but for now, it's unbearable.

-Kind of a walking simulator too grindy- While this is typical of survival games, this one seems to go to great lengths with forced marching to acquire resources. Walking 45 minutes in hopes to find a vein of iron so you can build a beginner building is currently not acceptable. This will be great when (imagining) trade routes are setup between major cities with players carrying goods between one point or another for profit. Now, it's simply not like that and spending an afternoon traveling to the center of the map just isn't fun.

-Targeting - This one needs some major work. It's soft targeting which is fine, but getting that soft target to work is another story, simply, 50% functional at this time.


PROS
+Great Community + Be good or bad this community has a can and will do attitude. I expect to see many undertakings setup by the community at large. Such as: trade routes, bounty hunters, trade locations -- think Eve Online.

+Fun + It's does give you a sense of enjoyment when you're working with others and solo to extend your existence. Just discovering the towns built across the countryside by players is quite entertaining.

+environments + I definitely enjoyed the difference in environments and how certain environments only spawn certain resources. This goes slightly against my negative comment, but it's a great idea, just bad that they excuted to require those Far away" resources on early buildings.

+Leveling system + Leveling system I really enjoyed as well
date: what you do levels that skill. So if I'm farming I will level farming ect.\n\nThere are a ton more items I could touch on both negative and good

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll admit that upon release on day 1 I was pretty excited about this one.
I'm even responsible for a friend of mine purchasing it along.
And what a mistake it was.

There is no incentive whatsoever in playing this game.
It fail as a survival, as food and shelter are ridiculously easy to acquire and mostly unnecessary even at night time as standing on or behind any player-made structure will completely baffle the AI.

The crafting while somewhat fun at first fall utter flat considering that it requires constant maintenance and that once you achieve any kind of progress it will be lost unless you or a guildmate log in every 24 hours.

And for what?

Being able to craft higher tiers weapon and armor that will end up being  useless as PVP or even PVE is mostly broken and offers no reward beside griefing someone.

How long can a game sustain a player base based on that?

Avoid like the SARS! (which coincidentally originate from the same region of the world).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After 94 hours of gameplay I figured it was time for the review. First off, this is a great sandbox experience when it comes to an MMO, in fact it's the best I've played since ultima online ( back in the day ). Don't like grinding out 2000 quests? No problem... Don't want to only be able to use 1 or 2 of the proffesions in game? Use them all! Wish those warrior skills you trained could be a different skill set now? Again not a problem. Want a fortress for you and your friends/guildies to call home? Build away!

Pros
A real SANDBOX MMO ( Ultima Online style, but better? )
Player territory ( You claim where you build, but feel free to move because the world is yours to claim )
Not another WoW clone... ( Thank you [insert spiritual being here] )
Even with limited character customization you feel unique with Equipment
1000s of hours worth of good times here
First game in years I've started friendships with people I met in game
I believe this will be the first MMO since vanilla WoW to build a true community of players
Most importantly however the game is a ton of fun (friends recommended, but not required)

Cons
No friends list/chat
No Guild Chat
Not a lot to say here since it's still pretty much brand new (can't bash early access games for not being polished)
Every human being hasn't tried it yet

Will try to keep this review up-to-date as much as possible ( no promises )

My experience thus far...
Started it up, got dumped on the edge of the map with no direction.
Wondered around exploring for a couple hours
Found a friendly stranger and started building a settlement with him
More friendly strangers joined
Got harrassed by a Red Player (criminal) a few times before he went away
Kept building up our new settlement
Red player comes back and starts smashing our stuff while I'm the only one online (had no walls or defenses yet)
I got frustrated and just picked up what I could and left
Headed far away from that area
Started a new settlement, met a new friend
Hung out awhile, all was well, all was quiet
Decided that area was to well and to quiet
So I moved again, but this time by choice
Found a guy in a prime location with a settlement started, but the walls were in ruins
Joined his guild
Rebuilt all the walls and arrow towers
Lived happily ever after
Got robbed
Revved up security
Live happily ever after... for now


At the end of the day greatest gaming experience I've had in a long time
Prior to finding this I was ready to give up on gaming due to the fact that no good games have been released in at least a decade... 1997+ UO was king, 1999 EQ Came up as UO's only true competition, 2000 Diablo II the greatest game in the world came out(not a mmo per se but get over it) 2004 WoW came in to change the face of MMOs forever (at the time it was great) 2005-2015 WoW became progressively more and more designed for a 5 year old to play it.... also in 2005-2015 every MMO ever tried to copy WoW exactly...

So yeah this game is a breath of fresh air, and I would recommend it to the world.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have a lot of Steam games but I rarely comment on them. This one is AMAZING. It's not complete so there bugs and areas that need improvement but I find the pacing to be pretty good.
Of course there are few things I'd like them to add such as friends showing up on minimap, home location on minimap, sharing cabins with friends and some way to share info. It may be possible to create books to leave notes for others to read but I haven't gotten that far.
If I had to be pressed I'd say it'd be closest to if Ultimate Online, Minecraft and Don't Starve had a baby pc game. There's survival elements, limited number of skill points that you can choose to level up or not and you can build cabins, forts, fences, etc. You can't mine the land so no changing of mountains but that may be a good thing.
For $20 it's cheap entertainment and the lat bit of advice I'd give is to spring for the next  level and pay $25 that way you'll save yourself the $2-$3 extra if you add on the DLC version after you realize you need more backpack space.  The game is very good and even tho it's early access it feels pretty complete to me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is a game in the survival genre, however on top of that it's a MMO since I believe you can have 1000 players in 1 server.

The moment you get into Tree of Life you have to choose a server, there is Europe, US and Korea to choose from. After you pick your region it's time for you to create a character, in the character customization you pick a skin color, hair color and you pick a boat.

The boat you pick is based on where you are going to spawn in the world. For example the bottom left boat (looking like a viking boat) that's the one I picked and I spawned in the bottom left. From there on out I met up with my friends on the beach and we went to trees and started chopping some trees, got some twigs and some logs. Then I pressed E" and looked at the crafting of the game.

After that I knew the game was awesome
date:
since you have to craft some kind of workbench and from there you can craft other structures that let you craft more and more. In order to craft the things you need a certain skill though.

Your skill points go up by using a skill more and more. For example if you want to level Tinkering you have to keep making things from Tinkering.

Now another thing is you get stats for doing these things
recommended:
for example for Tinkering I got a lot of "Con" which is Max HP increase. Now for using my axe a lot I got a lot of strength.

Now about the "Karma system" if you steal something you become red. This is for I believe 30 minutes. Now if you would murder someone you become red for 60 minutes.

The consequences of being red is that if you die you lose everything you have on you and some Experience points as well
hoursPlayed:
however I didn't notice that yet.

All in all I'd say the game is a blast where I only found 1 bug and that is some invisible mob that attacked me when I was on a mount. It only happened once though.

This game has a really bright future and I look forward to some good updates."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game with great potential! Very fun as an idea but falls short and I was very hopeful until just now when i read the recent patch notes which didn't address a single one of the following issues.

-The resource gathering is not engaging. No skills or even progression in resource gathering... Skilling up merely allows you to process the next item tier. Everything requires about 10 minutes of farming wood ( bassically clicking trees ) before you can craft with them. Processing these items into something usable takes another 10 minutes... WITH NO QUEUING. This means if you have to make 50 stone bricks or 50 iron Ore or whatever... you have to sit there and click the icon every 15 seconds. Autoclickers help but why do we have to bother with setting any of that up??

-Combat is not engaging. You bassically face your target and click... no skills... no progression. On top of that you have to deal with the terrible lag which means most attacks will not even register because of server desync, and you will have to do all your fighting while standing still.

-Nothing is worth killing... nothing... Bears were for a little while when you need oil and HQ oil... but other than that, nope. Most mobs drop coins which is the currency that is used mainly to repair buildings and you only need to kill about 10-20 things to get enough to repair your base fully. There are however, about 5 items that requires you to farm a specific mob that will require you about 1hour to just get to, kinda cool but bleh that time sink! OH let me say it again... there is no reason to pve in this game. The only pve available is an event that spawns a bunch of mobs to attack your base. Its novel and can be fun but the only reward is bassically resources to build a bigger base to fight against bigger attacks... This is not content, there is no strategy or skill involved in any of it... bassically build more walls and turrets win game!

-Coins(the intended currency) are worth very little. you can buy items from player made shops but since coins are so useless, most shops are not replenished and in the event someone is selling something you want, you have to travel to said shops to buy. Sooooooo.... if you actually do find something you want, this translates to about 30minutes to an hour to run there just to buy it.

-If nobody in your guild logs on, your base will slowly decay. Meaning you have about a week before someone will have easy enough access to pillage literally everything no matter how big your base is. This doesnt mean you simply have to log on but you literally have to be near the base to stop this despawning. Multiple bases or outposts are never ever worth it. Destroyed buildings also only have 24 hours to be repaired before vanishing. So don't ever go on vacation or anything or you lose stuff!

-pvp is bassically impossible because of dsync. Its still kind of fun to clash sometimes, but unfortunately, however good your gear is, it will bassically come down to who has more bandages and ginseng - meaning if someone is prepared to fight you and you are farming... you will always lose. Plus numbers matter... a lot... a lot lot and it doesnt make sense to farm together because resources are spread out, so you will get ganked, and you will probably have no chance

So besides all that, it can be a fun game still, I cleared a lot of hours, albeit a lot of those hours are spent logged in afk waiting for criminal rating to go down. There is great potential here, and if you read all that and still want to give it a try, go for it! If you have a small group it can be lots of fun for a bit but you wont find players to group with in game, and you wont find any end game. You might still get your 20 bucks worth out of it, but I feel you should know these things because there was an update from the devs about long term goals that did not adress a single one of these issues so dont say you werent warned. Gooduck!!

ps. I see a lot of complaints about theives but honestly this is not a huge problem and i'd like to give my 2 cents. If you are smart you will learn how to make yourself a difficult target for them (DO NOT BUILD GATES UNTIL YOU LITERALLY HAVE THE BEST LOCKS, instead just build walls and ladders ). The system does favor theiving, but danger is the only thing that makes this game fun! Safety lies in numbers... do not solo... make sure someone checks your base daily! Use your resources before logging off or log off with rares and you will not experience crippling losses.

pss. They are planning on releasing the game in 6-9 months so expect another wipe then.

BYE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty dang awesome for anyone looking for a softer Sandbox title that doesn't revolve around PvP.  PvP is a factor, but it rewards killing player-killers more than anything, since dying as a green-name only drops one random item as opposed to dying as a red-name which empties your whole inventory and is a persistent consequence that lasts for a full hour no matter how many times you die during it.   Also killing red-names keeps your name green instead of turning it red for killing someone, so you can basically kill griefers and loot all their ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• to punish them.

Skills are pretty varied, but the cool thing is that you gain stats per each skill level, and you only have so many points to level skills with, and each skill raises a certain stat every 1 and 4 levels (i.e. Farming raises Con every 1 level and Str every 4 levels - 20 Farming will give you +20 Constitution and +5 Strength). As a result, you can choose stuff to specialize in or be a jack of all trades if you wish to.   The skills range from crafting to combat to stuff like music and mining and farming.   No matter what you skill up though, you're benefiting it via stats.  So even if you're a hardcore Farmer and lack combat prowess, you'll still be able to take a ton of hits and still hurt enemies a good amount.

Exploration is a huge factor to the game as well, as you won't be able to find everything in one single area.  As the game adds more to find and do, exploration will be even more beneficial.   So while settling down is very smart to do (especially with other players since many hands will make the work much easier), exploring is still quite important as you can bring stuff non-native to your area and cultivate it.   For example, reindeers in the frozen regions can theoretically be bred in other areas as long as you grab a male and female one.   Crops like Lettuce, Corn, and various tree types also are scattered in different regions, so it's highly beneficial to bring some seeds or carry saplings over.

The coolest thing is that everything's persistent.  While some stuff does randomly respawn or regenerate in areas, you really do need to think before you recklessly cut/punch down an entire forest.

Survival is the name of the game here, but you're surviving more against the crazy nighttime environment more than other players.  It gives you a reason to team up with others and form pockets of civilization throughout the land.  Settlements can become cities, cities can become kingdoms, kingdoms can become empires... the potential is ridiculous.  As long as Odd One Games sticks to supporting and improving and adding to the game, I see nothing but good things to come out of Tree of Life.   If you liked stuff like ArcheAge or Rust but were turned off by the PvP-centric gameplay and wished for something more focused on cooperation and exploration in a hostile land that you need to band together to fight against, Tree of Life may be right up your alley.

I didn't even know anything about this game 12 hours ago.  But it left me presently surprised and I'm so stoked to see what Odd One Games has for the future, as long as they don't screw things up majorly.

And yes, there are bugs to be expected in Early Access.  Some people have issues more severely and frequently than others, but overall I've had a very positive first day in Tree of Savior and I strongly reccommend this game if you're looking to get lost in a true virtual world.

reviewText:

I wasn't sure what to expect with Tree of Life. Admittedly, the cartoonish graphics and rather lacking screenshots scared me, but I took a chance, and damn am I glad I did.

In a nutshell, Tree of Life takes the crafting and sandbox elements from a variety of games such as LIfe is Feudal, Reign of Kings, Rust and others and makes a simplistic game of survival and exploration.

The game has some bugs but for Early Access it's great and certainly worth the $20 pricetag. If you like sandbox games, give it a shot!

I logged in and watched my friend as he stood still looking into the distance, something came over me. I killed him. In cold blood i killed my only friend. My name turned red i had become a criminal!

This game has an amazing community - if you aren't a criminal, i learnt this the hard way. People looked at me differently, no-one wanted to share their logs with me or even let me eat from the same apple tree. I decided i would get them back all the kids that used to look down at me, it was my time to become a legend.

I saw a kid chopping down a tree. I killed him. maybe that will teach them to belittle me for being a criminal, criminals have feelings too.

Little did i know he was in a guild. They quickly sounded the alarms and there was a guild bounty on my head i had become an outcast! Not wanting to die i fled to the ocean and made my way towards the desolate desert where i quickly learnt i was not the only criminal in this world, oh no i was not alone. I created a band of criminal minds and we built an anti peace headquarters in the harshest terrain. This was our home, no-one would judge us here.

That was untill the ..... Nation attacked. We didn't stand a chance we were chased by men riding bulls and we fled our humble abode. we had no home but we had each other, and home is where the heart is.

Fast forward 2 hours we came across a nice plot of land in a quiet area and decided to stay clear of our criminal past times whilst we gained strength. The strength needed to win. we may have been outcast but we will come back stronger and wage war/

TL/DR: Don't kill people straight away, you will be killed.

This game is really fun. i've missed the days where i would buy a game on rust and 2 weeks later realise that i had forgotten to eat shower and drink, this is one of those games. Set an alarm or you will forget what day it is. Best game ive purchased this year! Great potential can't wait to see it evolve

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAre there still plenty of bugs and gameplay balance issues to sort out?  Absolutely.  Is this game still amazingly fun and addicting with an addicting crafting system?  Oh yes... So worth it.  This is the game to escape to when you're in the mood for an MMO, but don't feel like playing grindy quests with generic and unimpressive lore.  I've put in 12 hours of gameplay in 3 days while working full time, going to school part time, and still making time for my kids.  Yes; it's that addicting.  I need sleep...

Early Access Review

I purchased this game for myself and my brother when I saw it was on sale and knew I could afford it. I have not regretted it in the least. There have been many bugs yes but nothing too horrible as to call it game breaking unless you give up easy or are easilly frustrated.

First off I do agree that the prices on the backpack and mount could be lowered just a little, but at the same time you have to understand and or play the game a while(of have done many early access games) to understand that while the in game items purchased may cost more than the game or even 3 times over(if you get it all) what you are doing is support the devs. If you had a awesome gaming store in your town open up that had exactly what you wanted, would you not support them by buying from them instead of another store? Same concept.

I do like the systems they have in place. They definitly need a good bit of honing, like the placements of some of the crafting tiers(tinkering gets black powder fairly early but area to harvest sulfur is a misty area" so it is very difficult to find safely

Flawed combat mechanics, Grindy difficulty built around a exponentially hard crafting tree, Poorly implemented criminal, hunger and durability system which continues to eat away at a player's gameplay experience as they progress.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is a lot like a lot of the other survival games out there like ARK. The major differences I would say is that TOL is a bit more casual and in TOL you can kind of play more of a different role when it comes to how you want to play the game. In ARK you basically have to build and craft in TOL you can just go old school MMORPG and go kill mobs get drops heal yourself and keep killing mobs for equipment. Thats good because it is a faster way to play if your are by yourself. One thing this game definently needs is for bronze coins to be able to repair weapons, I know you can smelt weapons down for ingots but it would be better if you could just stick with one weapon and save inventory space. Also the dead sailor thing replacing a tin ore drop is well unique but a little odd. Overall this game kind of reminds me of Ragnarok Online a little bit because of the uniqueness and weirdness of drops, kill an dead sailor corpse and get tin! Funny.

It is a fun game so far that I have played, there are some combat issue or rather targetting issues but perhaps I havnt figured out how to target correctly? So far I have only come across like 3 keybuttons, E for inventory and char stats, M for map and Z to sit so hopefully they add a lot more. The other thing that is kind of annoying is how limited stacks of items can kind of be but I guess later on with wagons etc it becomes a lot easier. Also it seems like there are alot of abandoned stuff around and guild castles/cities that are inaccessible. With only 3 servers you would think the world would be densely populated but I only saw 1 person.


So far this game is an 8/10 to me. I look forward to more people playing and the devs introducing new stuff. I actually like this more than ARK and a lot of other survival games and I think that is because it is more casual.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While I like this game and I think it may have potential, the community seems relatively small or non existant. On average I see one person every other hour or so? Maybe less honestly. I heard that it was quite large and filled with griefing before the crime update but I didn't get my hands on it until after that patch.

It's very grindy as well. So if you're into grinding (I somewhat am, gives me a goal I guess or I'm just a glutton for punishment) then you will like the skill and leveling style this game provides. One thing that would have deterred me that I didn't fully understand until I started playing and got further in, Mastery points. You have a certain amount of mastery points and once those are all used you can no longer gain levels in skills. It's a bit annoying for a completionist type like myself. I suppose it has its merrits in forcing you to work together to craft and build the good stuff but if you like being self reliant, it hurts.

All in all, its not a terrible play but it's not a great one either. It kept my attention for probably about 3 - 4 weeks or so. They do release updates frequently from what I've experienced and what I've read which is always a good sign with EA games. But thats a rant for another time. Hope this review helps.

My first little review:

Pros
Non-linear game play
Sandbox - do what you want
Crafting is fun
Graphics are ok

Cons
Map is kind of small
Resources can be far apart
Need to be with others for full enjoyment of game... limited single player enjoyment

All in all its a fun little game.  Just make sure you log in time to time to make sure your stuff is not gone.
Community is helpful, not too many griefers.

-Manfzain

Early Access Review

Here's the only reason you should buy this game.

All the other build/survival games like this, and many exist and are made daily, are not MMOs. You get stuck on a server that has 20 kiddies that you beat up and leave the server so you're the only one left. Then you have to go to another server and start all over.

The community is large and the population is strong. Beat up some bads? No worries, the server population isn't going to tank and all your hard work and time doesn't go down the drain.

Buy this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Bought this game on aFriday night, and started playing with a couple of friends. Now 30 hours in and totally addicted.

The game does have a couple of bugs, and does crash every so often, but as it is an online game, no info is lost when crashing. Totally expected with early access.

Game is very enjoyable with friends, and the community (at least on the Asia server), is generally very friendly and willing to help. It is also best with friends so that you can share out the work; such as one person specialising in carpentry, sewing, or farming. That way you can make the most progress in the least amount of time.

If you commit crimes and become marked as a criminal however, you will get attacked by about 20% of the people you come across in game. You aren't even safe in your own base. Recommend building up a base with walls before going rogue/getting into a guild war because of this.

There are some player griefers. We encountered 2 guilds who would come across and attempt to steal our things or attack us without provocation. They have only made up a very small part of the people we have come across, and so if you are someone who avoids games such as this for that reason, don't worry too much.

10/10 would recommend, I would just say that it is best to find at least one other person you know to play with, because trying to level up all of your skills on your own would take a very long time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally an early access game, where early access is only ment for beeing able to fund the progression at the project. The developers actually work on it as hard as possible!

The game itself is really good at its actual state and has a lot of potention.
I, as a player having approx 400 games on steam, am really satisfied by the game design, the expandability, and the progression this games makes. Theyve chosen the right path.

This game is also ment for PvE and PvP players alike, while PvE are protected through a really well designed Crimesystem, and PvP people can attack each building, but get marked with the Crime-Tag, which makes it really hard for PvP players.
More details u will probably find in other reviews, but this game is definatly worth its 20 bugs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me get the obvious questions out of the way. Is it worth it? Yes!

Tree of life is a survival RPG and multiplayer game. When I say it is a multiplayer game, I am not kidding. In order to get the most out of this game you will need some friends to play with. Also, you will need an external form of communication because this game does not offer global chat, so finding your friends will be nearly impossible without it.

While this game is very enjoyable, it is by no means perfect. Since it is in early access you should expect that the game will drastically change from time to time. This can compltely change how you play the games at times. If you can put up with that, then you will have a blast.

Tree of life is very fun and deep, but I found myself gathering the same resources over and over again just to craft needed materials to level up my skills. I would also STRONGLY recommend buying the adventure pack because you will find that your item slots fill up very quickly. You can expect to build a lot of excess junk in the game and see a lot of it filling the world. Hope you like gathering materials!

Overall, Tree of Life is a great early access game that, in some ways, feels like a completed game already. So, if you have a few friends, $20, and some times, then Tree of Life is the game for you!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is basically what Rust ( http://store.steampowered.com/app/252490/ ) should have been. The only things that desperately need fixed are:
1) Make it not so dark at night, you literally can't see anything that's not directly in front of you
2) Allow full screen without crashing
3) Allow you to actually exit to lobby without crashing
4) Maybe a guild friendly fire toggle or something. That way if you and some guild members go out hunting, you don't spend half the time apologizing for accidentally hitting each other.
5) Better hit boxes (sort of goes along with 4)

Overall the game is pretty good, and I'd definitely recommend it for $20.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played for bit over 10 hours so far:

Pros:
- Tons to do (can be a bandit/criminal, a trader, farmer, nomad, builder, crafter etc)
- Fun with friends
- So far, a friendly community
- Old structures get destroyed/decayed naturally

Cons:
- Tough to play solo
- Graphics are mediocre
- Grindy (unless you like grinds)
- Night is long, and real dark
- Can't repair armor and weapons (yet?)

Having fun so far

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first, I was ecstatic to start playing the game. I bought it, played it for a bit, then wrote a review (pretty much entirely for the free Adventurer Pack), which was previously positive. But now, as I played the game for almost 4 hours, I can safely say that's it's not very good in this state.


Price

This game costs $22 in Early Access. That would be fine if the game was more so near completion, but as it stands, it is not (but who knows, this was supposedly in alpha for 3 years). So, I suggest spending your $20 elsewhere.

Mechanics

There are some okay mechanics. The food system for example is not awful, although about 2/500 go down every few seconds, the abundance of food you manage to get pays for that. The mastery system is pretty balanced as well, but sadly that's it. The other core mechanics, building, PVPing, and whatnot are not very good in their current stage.

Buildings work okay for the most part, but they easily break making it really annoying. Say you log out for something like 12+ hours. Then, when you log in most of your base is going to be destroyed by either monsters, or players. However, when you destroy building it goes into a destroyed state, where it stays for 24 hours, and can be repaired by coins. If you don't get back in that 24h, you can say goodbye to your base.

PVPing works as follows: if you kill a yellow player, you become red. If you kill a red player, you stay your color. You can become red by destroying other players things, and by stealing things from people too. Being red however brings a huge disadvantage, and no advantages at all (it makes you drop all items .

will edit l8r again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is slow to start. Many of the hostiles are neigh impossible to kill yourself until after some major grind fest. I do say Grind however you level up by using tools and different weapon types, it really gives you stats like Str from hitting an enemy with a hammer based weapon and Dex from using a dagger.

The largest pain is the need to grind up crafting skills in order to really craft yourself a decent home to hide away from mobs. Those Mobs also tend to damage and break your home piece by piece, this creating a need to constantly rebuild and repair in order to maintain your safe homestead.

All in all I believe it to be a really good game especially since the people in it are majority quite helpful.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***Edit 4/28/2016

I am changing my review from not recommend to recommend.  The developers have balance the appearance of random stone.  While there is still a strong benefit to having a quarry in your possession, it is no longer game breaking to not have access to one.  I don't know if my post had anything to do with that change, but if it did, the devs respond to concerns very quickly.

Overall 4/5:
Tons of fun and highly recommended to everyone.

Gameplay: 4/5:
It is very fun, and only slightly repetitive.  However, there is a large variety of things to do and if you bored, just take a break and pick something else.

CO-OP: 5/5:
This game almost requires co-op to truly love it.  There are so many different skills and different paths to take that you can't do it all.  Getting a guild together to can help each other in ways that is truly fun.  If all you want to do is chop trees and collect rocks, you really will be as much of a benefit as the town planner/builder and the weapon/armor smith.

SOLO: 4/5
However, if you want to play solo it still works well.  You can get your own full base up and running and be partially skilled in everything.  I met a lady with quite the nice little base.  She just was kind to the people around her so they help protect her.


Being an open world MMO sandbox, really gameplay is all that really matters for a rating and it is fun.

There are still some graphical glitches and bugs that you need to logout and back in for, but it is relativly low for a Beta game.

With the exceptions of the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• fully blocking stones when they knew it was screwing over people, the majority of the people I have played with have been a pleasure and a lot of fun.  There were plenty of people who stole everything they could before we got our walls up and other who killed all our animals daily, but that is easily resolved by building walls (which is possible now that you can find stone under a 15min walk away to randomly find one).



***Old Post***

I love this game and absolutly hate giving it a do not recommend, but here I go.

Gameplay: 4/5
Loads of fun.  Minus the stone epidemic.

Stone: 0/5
Most of the resources in the game are random spawns all over.  This works and is fun.  However, Stone is not.  Stone spawns in an area, and with very few random stones (not enough to run a base off of), all the stone is in those locations.

So, here is a story of playing this game.

Day 1:
Run off literally 20min into the middle of nowhere.  Find a good flat area with all the resources relativly close.  Start building.

Day 2:
A couple other people settle near you, you are friendly and everyone gets along.  You help eachother, find nearby locations and share them with one another.

Day 3:
You notice a person at each stone area building guild halls.  You walk over and express your concerns about them walling in all the stone.  They assure you they just want to be close to it.  There it plenty of stone so you don't worry about it.  No one guild could ever use up all the stone, so literally the only reason to block it off is if you are activly attempting to ruin other peoples game play for no reason other then to ruin other peoples game play.

Day 4:
They have blue prints for walls completely surrounding the stone.  You ask what's going on.  They are rude and insult you.  You jump over the wall templates and try to get stone since you know it is going to be blocked off by the next day.  They start killing you.  Then again.  Then again.  Woohoo, this game is awesome isn't it?

Day 5:
Now you can't get stone and there is no point to playing anymore.  Yay for spending $15 for a flawed game that lets players be complete jerks with zero reprecussions.  No bother venturing out and finding a new area, the stone is all walled in by this point!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Several things that I can say about this game:

1. $20 is a lot of money for some people. If they are not sure it's worth it or not, I suggest go find Let's Play" videos first to get an idea of what this game is about.

2. There's PvP element. Some people hate it
date: some people don't mind it. The mechanics is simple: When you commit criminal act (stealing/attacking someone enough times/killing someone) your name will turn red for a duration. During this period anyone who kills you will make you drop your entire inventory. When you are a law-abiding citizen on the other hand
recommended: your name will be yellow. When you have yellow name tag
hoursPlayed: you only drop 1 RANDOM inventory item when you die
voteText: which is much easier to deal with. There are people who kill for fun and watch other people's hours of work go to waste in this game. If you can deal with that then this game might be enjoyable for you (me
helpfulPercent: for example
votesHelpful: I don't get red names and I don't mind getting killed).\n\n3. The tech tree is hard to climb because at some point the skills need grinding. If grinding can be rated on a scale of 1 to 10 with 10 being tedious. I would rate this game's skill grinding a 5 or 6. Not too easy but also not exceedingly time wasting (plus some of you might enjoy the process of getting all the materials for grinding). Also there's no tutorial
votesTotal: so you are either on your own or you can try asking other people about things you don't know.\n\n4. This is a co-op/team game! You cannot master every skill by yourself. Working together is better in terms of productivity and safety. "Strength in numbers" is a very fitting description for this game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After putting some hours in and building up a decent settlement, I have a decent grasp on this game.

Tree of Life is a survival/‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•me where you start on a beach with nothing and then go about punching trees etc to craft various tools. Where the game differs from other traditional survival games is in its scope and depth.
There are a lot of various buildings are technologies to work towards and a slew of different resoruces to gather and craft. The game looks very cute and runs extremely well.

I get a sense of achievement when I make something as simple as a wheelbarrow and find it enjoyable to craft different things that ultimately just help me gather and build faster.
PvE is fun, there are a host of different mobs throughout the world, some more dangerous than others. The combat feels fun and there is a whole host of weapons to unlock and craft, each with their own points system.

PvP is something I haven't done much of. Usually when I come across another player they are friendly but I have had a run in with a few red players that I caught stealing or breaking into other people towns.
The criminal system works well in this game. Basically if you damage something or steal you become a yellow player meaning that towers etc will shoot you and players know you are not such a nice person. Continue this and add in some murder and you are a red player...simple as that.

The game feels very fresh. Its a large open world filled with bases/towns/cities that players have made and try to keep alive. When you build a semi large town the AI will announce raids on you. You can either pay them off with various resources or take on the raid which is fun.

The main thing the games suffers from now is playerbase. I play on the ASIA server and the starting island and a bit inland is quite populated but the higher zones are quiet, but the community is very friendly.

You can basically do anything in this game and they all have seperate skills to level, be it logging, ranching, breeding, farming, mining, blacksmith, swords, daggers, bows, healing, sewing, martial arts and many many many more.

It's a great game, truly my favourite find in 2015 and I look forward to where the developers will take it next.

8/10 - Needs more players and starter shields!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While more sandbox than rpg, this game has more than enough potential to be worth investing money into it's development. It won't be the next Minecraft breakthrough mostly because of the people out there who think it's fun to cause trouble.
This is a PvP game at it's core. Crafting is a main component to survive. Most of my interacrtions with people in the game have been plesant. One the other hand, there are enough people who sneak in and destroy your hard work or livestock that it can tear you up inside. Taking 3 hours to find and bring a chicken to my camp then having it killed while I was offline did not give me a warm fuzzy.
If you enjoy Don't Starve and Minecraft while wanting an MMO experience, this might be enjoyable.
