reviewText:
Early Access Review

I read reviews before purchasing the game and then read reviews after purchasing the game. The reason my review is so long is because I want people to get excited about this excellent game so that the devs recieve more support and (hopefully) respond accordingly with more work and content. Also FYI I bought the DLC it wasn't given to me, this game is just good.

Having said that:

This game is like Runescape meets Life is Feudal, then this game has its own special flare which I enjoy very much.

Reasons its like Runescape:
Graphics
Talent Progression

Reason its like Life is Feudal:
Building
Crafting

What stands out,

Player Consequence system:
What this does is when a player steals, breaks, or attacks other people and their things he or she is marked a criminal. This changes their name to appear red and if they are killed everything they carry drops.

Combat:
Soft Targeting means you hold down the attack after looking at a target. You then lock on automatically with your first attack and then can move around and look around while still attacking (as long as you stay near the target).
***This is not true with projectile weapons.

Being an outlaw:
In this game you truly can do whatever you want. I played as an outlaw for a little while and something I really appreciated was how when I went to steal something five things happened
1. My lockpick was used up
2. A Trace of Evil" appeared on the ground to let the players know a crime was commited at that very spot
3. I was only allowed to steal one item
4. There was a timer for when anyone could steal another item giving the victim time to reinforce and protect his valuables.
5. My name turned red for everyone to see and I was at risk of being hunted down and killed for my crime.

Building destruction:
You can repair your destroyed buildings but you have to be an active player to ensure it says protected otherwise your city will turn to ruins and your neglect will show. What this does is makes sure you are playing the game and if you arent gives other players the opportunity to build something where your city will eventually crumble.

Lastly
date: The different playstyles:\nYou can be a Builder
hoursPlayed: Tinker
voteText: Blacksmith
helpfulPercent: Archer
votesHelpful: Supplier
votesTotal: Shopkeeper
votesFunny: Outlaw
commentsCount: Guild Leader
column16:
etc. These things will garuntee to fill you time up. You can play a vital role in peoples experience and if you decide you want to change all it will take is supply and time. You can easily go from a Blacksmith to a Tinker and still retain all your Blacksmith ability.

Truly a beautiful thing the devs should be proud of.

Pros:
Graphics are relaxing in a Runescape type of way
Consequence system
Theft system
A true "Play it your own way" game
Community is fantastic
Map is HUGE and diverse
You can make shops and sell things!
Active Developers (It is sad that this needs to be mentioned... What has gaming come to?)

Cons:
Early Access (You know that upon purchase so this con isn't very justifiable)
Grind-y (A pro for some and a con for others)
Difficult to get started (FInd people to work with before going on your own!)
Has a Lame beginning (Until you know what you are doing you are bored out of your mind. Play for at least 5 hours)

I have noticed that a lot of the cons people post are a consequence of early production which people should not be surprised by when buying a game that is not completed yet. A lot of other cons are just mechanics of the game which are easily countered through mechanics that the devs purposely created such as "Enemies spawning in base" easily countered by Arrow Towers which you can create early on.

My reccomendation if you get the game is to play with other players until you get a good feeling of what to do and how to do it. WARNING! This game will seem lame intially because there is so much to do you don't know WHAT to do.

Level Carpentry first. Level Farming second. Level Tinkering third. Everything else will either happen along the way or you will know enough about what you are doing to figure it out yourself.

My reccomendation if you DONT get the game is to follow it and keep up. Make sure the developers stay active and the content keeps getting polished and pushed out into release."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's the only MMO I've ever played in that let's me be a nomad merchant traveling a vast world selling wares I acquire and at the same time a bard, spreading news across lands ravaged by war and bandits. You can be a mercenary / bounty hunter, working for coin or gear and delivering proof of a targets death via screenshot and the steam forums to the client upon assasination.

You can be a blacksmith and forge weapons and metal armor.
A tailor making cloth and leather gear.
A carpenter, building walls, buildings and even things like mailboxes (not implemented yet)

A word of advice however. there is no global or trade/auction chat. This is a more or less medieval world where news is by word of mouth from people you meet and trade with as you travel. It is a savage dangerous world where having allies and friends means life or death. You're welcome to travel alone,but know that you may be attacked and killed at any time by roaming player bandits who sometimes even travel in packs. If you have good gear you might win a fight, but in a group you will always be safer.

It is a harsh world where, if you don't carry food to eat you will slow to a weak walk and become an easy target because you can't run.

There is next to no tutorial at all. You make a character and you are dropped off at the beach of the island in a location you choose. Players are generally very nice and helpful if you have questions, but you will encounter ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s who prey on travelers and will no doubt demand your money or your life.

One more thing (sorry for the long post) If you think you can build an entire castle and every building you can by yourself, you can, but it will fall to ruin every time because you're just one person trying to keep up with task of maintaining an entire town meant for roughly 15-20 people to perform the work it needs to stay alive.

Oh yeah, reputation spreads fast as fire. If you live the life of a theif or bandit, the server will know through the steam forums and you will become hunted. Do good deeds and people you encounter in your travels will always be glad to see you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So for this type of early access game, you have to expect things not to work and you have to maintain that mentality if you want to play. With that said, I think they have a great thing going here. It does take some great things from other games but they have made it unique on it's own merit.

Tree of life is great for people who like a steady progression/rpg/adventure/build game :) The only troubles the game seems to have are the penalty system for players who choose to steal, vandalize, and kill property and othe players. Most of the other complaints are simply out of ignorance of how the game works....things like towers not being worth a damn because people can steal the arrows out of them - You can place locks (actually pad locks) on everything you own to keep people from stealing. Of course there is lockpicking in game which comes with a price :).

Figuring out the game and getting together with friends to build a town and grow your character is amazingly fun and it actually encourages you to make friends quickly. Soloing is a bit tough but i've seen some manage it (but for how long?)

This game is highly addicting in that you always want the next thing, what's over the next hill, what can i do to get more people to join my town? All these things make the game delightfully engaging and it's not even done yet!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wanted to start out by saying, Tree of Life has compared to games like Rust and DayZ. Nothing could be further from the truth though. Tree of Life, a sandbox survival mmo, has pvp as an optionable game feature, like most of the other games it is compared too. However, it does not suffer from pvp being an over-centralized playstyle due to a criminal system. What this means is killing on sight isn't and won't be a normal for how the community behaves in game. Which was a huge problem for games of similar ilk. With that said, let the review begin!

THE REVIEW

Tree of Life is like most of the bandwagon crafting survival games out there on Steam. At least, at it's core it is. So, why would I recommend it? While it isn't very original, what it does, it does right. And by that I mean you really get the feeling this game was made by developers who are also gamers at heart. You'll start on an island, your starting position determined by which boat you picked when creating your character. At which point you will adventure into this huge island prospecting the area. You may eventually find a place to call your own, or a group of people looking for another member to strengthen their group.

That brings up the community portion of the game. It's quite hard to survive on your own. You'll need to invest more time into the game then a group would, and you'll need to level all of your skills, where as groups can have people who specialize in certain skills. In that sense, the game is quite hard if you demand to play lone wolf. But, it's also very rewarding once you make it on your own.

The way levelings work in this game is quite brilliant. I've heard many say it's similar to Ultima Online.  Rather than levels persay, you have masteries. Skills basically. These level up and give you stats based on what type of skill they are. The system isn't entirely perfect. While skills level up, most attack skills don't seem to do anything at a higher level beyond just giving out those base stats. Crafting related skills are essential to unlocking new recipes. What this means is attack skills have little going for them right now.

Some skills are way harder then others to level. While that's fine for something like Blacksmithing, it doesn't really feel deserved on a skill like archery. On the flip side, some skills are too easy to level. Farming is a great example of that. But, the system has lots of promise. There is also a cap. This cap exists to let someone dabble into all of the said skills, but only master 8 or so of them. This helps prevent people from grinding to a point of god hood. The cap works wonders in that regard. Want to try fishing out? You can. Don't like it, try something else out. It doesn't force you down one road, but grants customization to make your experience more unique.

This is an early access game. And like most of them, it can be buggy, have it's exploits, and it's balancing issues. The reason this isn't a deal breaker though is because of the developers and their decisive action. Is there a game breaking bug surrounding the criminal system? Yes. What do the developers do? Work on fixing it immediately, and give the people a warning that any future abuse of exploits can result in a permanent ban from the game. They tried their hardest to stop the problem, and they stopped it in it's tracks before it did any more damage. Griefing in ways the criminal system does not cover is also another issue, one they are already hard at work fixing, if they haven't fixed it already with a patch I just finished downloading. It's hard to rag on the game for any one particular issue like some other reviews are doing out there, because the issue will most likely be dealt with in a day or a few at most.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I had originally got this gift from a friend to play the game with him and some other friends. Effectively we were going to work on a single settlement like base together and have fun by those means. There were some interesting elements to the game that I enjoyed. I enjoyed the leveling system of skills and stuff. Its not unique to this game alone, but this was the only game with a system like this that had a good review on the game. I did my fair share of reading the reviews on this game as well. Constantly throughout I was worried about the constantly reoccuring things. One, which was the elephant in the room was the over populated servers. It is extremely difficult even finding a place to put a base that was in a good place or even around decent resources. Didnt help that most of them simply were active anymore. Easily could break down the inactive bases and place it with your own, but then you become criminal for it. So it was somethign we had to deal with and put ourselves in a really crappy place.

The next major thing and the biggest thing of why I am writing this review and why I am basically going to be stopping playing this game. Raiders. People are literally just leveling their lockpicking and then just get by by raiding other peoples hard work. That kind of stuff becomes extremely frustrating and often times, the few times I found people on they were extremely caucious about my presence. And it was with good reason. I even got accused of raiding someones base just because I was resource mining in the area when they got online.  I know, its sorta comes with the terretory with these kinds of games, but there could be so many ways this kind of community could be prevented. I mean come on, the game literally has a skill to build on that specifically works to raid peoples bases. Its just frustrating. It takes next to no effort for one guy just to break into someones base and just steal everything.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still very early in development, but you can see the big picture already.
The graphic and animation style is in-a-nutshell Wildstar meets Minecraft. Like in WS the graphic style is very unique and cartoonish, with big oogly eyed PCs and cudly NPCs. The crafting system is, like almost all modern sandbox games, a little bit like MC, though there are more crafting and work stations, like shops for example.
The mix of WS and MC can also be seen in the (still w.i.p.) world: like WS dense forrest areas change with vast spaces of nothingness with a few NPC monsters sprinkled over the scenery - and like most public MC servers abandond player hpuses and bases are wildly scattered all over.
At this moment the gameplay consistis mostly of gathering resources and building your base - nothing else.
The combat with monsters is spartanic at best, while PlayerKiller attacks seem to be the main thread.
Mabye this game will become a nice sandbox mmo for casual gamers, and I hope so, because it looks quite nice if you like the toon style - but at this early state the game content is unexciting, limited and neither a challenge nor a fun time for survival gamers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great Sandbox MMO, easy to play, easy to learn (with google lol)... Entertaining building, and pvp.

HOWEVER, the reason I am giving this game thumbs down is because of the lack of players.  The game is far too large for the player base.  You are lucky if you see 5 people in a 4 hour period.  It isn't fun because of this reason.  Unless you are coming to this game with a group of 5-10 you arent going to be able to progress at a fast enough rate.  Eventually you will get bored of the game because to build you need to chop hundreds of trees, mine hundreds of copper/iron/mithril nodes... It just becomes tedious with a small group.

So until this game either gets shrunk or there is a mass increase of players it just isnt worth it to play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun sandbox game as a solo player but as of 6/01/15 It's pretty far away from completion. Weapon masteries don't seem to do anything but give stats but if you want stats crafting gives the same faster with actual content unlocked. Aggressive field monsters currently can spawn inside your walled off  base and attack your stuff when in range either way while you are offline, though killing monsters will give you coins to repair it easily enough but some small buildings like basic fences and basic crafting stations aren't repairable. Arrows take forever to make and 20 minutes of grinding will probably give your tower enough to kill one enemy while you are logged off but the range is too far and hits enemies not even attacking your stuff.

Stats don't seem to be balanced at the moment, STR seems to be the best stat by far giving 1~1 damage per 5 STR with any weapon letting you do nice unarmed damage and not have to deal with the low durability weapons. DEX seems completely useless at the moment giving 1 critical per point which isn't 1% and 1 stamina that doesn't affect regen speed. CON only gives 1 health per point, might scale with stacking inventory space with high quality bandages and having an amazing weapon and armor and INT/magic isn't implemented. Weapons have no differences currently with the same speed and range while giving you an x~x damage boost for 1 durability per hit even on rocks and trees, pretty useless without a high level blacksmith/tinker crafting them for more damage and durability.

Currently there is no way to tie livestock to you so people can make a building outside of your walls if you don't use stone walls and jump over them to kill them with no penalty. As with above mounts are randomly spawning rarely apparently but they don't log off with you and suffer the same problem as above.

When these problems are fixed I would recommend the game but this is just the beginning of Early Access and will be fixed.

EDIT as of 6/4/15:People being able to jump over walls has been fixed by increasing their sizes fixing a lot of issues. They also turned arrows from 10 per craft to 40 and reduced the dumb extra  requirements of above copper fixing monsters at night mostly while making aggressive day monsters not attack buildings. They announced plans of a leash item to tie livestock to you but it isn't implemented yet. I will recommend the game now but be warned if you care about PvP or fighting monsters weapon masteries still don't do anything and magic is still not implemented, rollbacks from server crashes have been frequent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Seems confusing at first, but once you understand the crafting system there is logic behind it.  If you like to build / explore this is a wonderful game even right at launch, plenty of grinding to do so that you can build yourself a base and possibly gear.  I'm currently to the point where I can almost build a cabin / forge / tailor but not quite ready to build those setups.

I would complain that I need to craft things I don't need just to level up the skill... but that comes with the type of game this is and is unavoidable.

If you just want to be a pirate (Murderer) good luck doing so solo, you need someone to supply you with gear and if you don't want to spend the time like I am to grind up my crafting skills then you are in for a bad time.

Overall I am impressed, the only BIG problem at the moment is hit detection... sometimes the game decides that you are not hitting a creature / player when clearly you are or should be in range to do so.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fun game and I'm glad I dove in to purchase it right when it came out. The initial impression I got with it was from the visuals and I really hope they improve them to allow the user to ingest such awesome game play and features more easily.

The game play is the traditional open world, survival, pvp type that is over saturating the market however the way that it's executed begs a look into this diamond in the rough. With traditional RPG elements and profession system, an easy way to summarize this game would be to say it's a miniaturized sandbox MMORPG with a focus on a close-knit commmunity that'll push people to interact given the island environment you play on. That's not to say the island is small since it took me 30-40 minutes of continuous running to reach the opposite side but with the server cap of 1,000 players I imagine it'll feel much smaller.

The cute soundtrack and graphical representation may give off a false sense of innocence however this game is harsh and challenging. If you decide to go smash a skeleton with your new club on your first night then expect to die. When you do die you'll spawn at the location of your body but as a ghost with a 3 minute respawn time and you can grab souls around the area to take off chunks of the timer.

All in all I am impressed with what is already here and I can see myself playing it for a long time. I look forward to see what will be added in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun sandbox game as a solo player but as of 6/01/15 It's pretty far away from completion. Weapon masteries don't seem to do anything but give stats but if you want stats crafting gives the same faster with actual content unlocked. Aggressive field monsters currently can spawn inside your walled off  base and attack your stuff when in range either way while you are offline, though killing monsters will give you coins to repair it easily enough but some small buildings like basic fences and basic crafting stations aren't repairable. Arrows take forever to make and 20 minutes of grinding will probably give your tower enough to kill one enemy while you are logged off but the range is too far and hits enemies not even attacking your stuff.

Stats don't seem to be balanced at the moment, STR seems to be the best stat by far giving 1~1 damage per 5 STR with any weapon letting you do nice unarmed damage and not have to deal with the low durability weapons. DEX seems completely useless at the moment giving 1 critical per point which isn't 1% and 1 stamina that doesn't affect regen speed. CON only gives 1 health per point, might scale with stacking inventory space with high quality bandages and having an amazing weapon and armor and INT/magic isn't implemented. Weapons have no differences currently with the same speed and range while giving you an x~x damage boost for 1 durability per hit even on rocks and trees, pretty useless without a high level blacksmith/tinker crafting them for more damage and durability.

Currently there is no way to tie livestock to you so people can make a building outside of your walls if you don't use stone walls and jump over them to kill them with no penalty. As with above mounts are randomly spawning rarely apparently but they don't log off with you and suffer the same problem as above.

When these problems are fixed I would recommend the game but this is just the beginning of Early Access and will be fixed.

EDIT as of 6/4/15:People being able to jump over walls has been fixed by increasing their sizes fixing a lot of issues. They also turned arrows from 10 per craft to 40 and reduced the dumb extra  requirements of above copper fixing monsters at night mostly while making aggressive day monsters not attack buildings. They announced plans of a leash item to tie livestock to you but it isn't implemented yet. I will recommend the game now but be warned if you care about PvP or fighting monsters weapon masteries still don't do anything and magic is still not implemented, rollbacks from server crashes have been frequent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: It's an amazing game if you make friends early, buy the adventurer pack, and find somebody to mentor you.
This game is NOT very kind to new players - especially the ones who stick to themselves and don't want to merge with a bigger group.

Prepare for a grind fest and to be killed alot until you are of decent levels/skills/gear/etc. End game (if you can call it that) is alot of fun. I enjoy it alot though, so I'll give it a thumbs up because I like where the DEVs are headed. It's not their fault some people suck.

Pros:
~Cute graphics
~Beautiful musical score
~You can have hours of fun exploring, trading, making friends/allies
~The community is kind...
~ :coronet: ANIMALS :coronet:
~ YOU CAN RIDE COWS!!!!!

Cons:
~The beginning tutorial sucks, and the game doesn't really tell you how to do stuff overall.
~The community is kind... to your face.
~It's almost necessary to befriend a large guild, unless you enjoy starting over every time you get  on or living out of your backpack(s?)
~If you don't do the above, prepare to have your animals slaughtered for seemingly no reason; your locks will be picked, your buildings destroyed while you're away from base, afk, or offline
~It will be difficult starting out if you don't immediately buy a backpack (either from steam or a guild who's selling stuff)
~There is quite  bit of guild drama, and most likely, you'll somehow get involved in it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Tree of Life is a MMO RPG SURVIVAL game that is most similiar to Archeage. It takes on a cartoony look and is set on a large, multi-biomed island in the middle of an ocean. The progression in the game is centered around leveling, which often requires players to grind by either crafting duplicates of the same item or by attacking resource nodes/monsters.

This game is in EARLY Alpha build, so keep in mind that any review cannot fully cover the finished product.

Combat (PvP and PvE)
Combat is extremely lacking in this version of the game. Combat can be summed up in three categories: Auto-Attacking, Bandaging, and Running.

Auto-Attacking
Whether you are fighting monsters or players, how you deal damage is mostly the same. To fight, all that you must do is move close enough for your target to be highlighted and hold down your left mouse button until they are dead. The weapon you most likely will use to kill will either be a sword or another weapon that requires only one hand. This is because currently, the two-hander skill is broken and two-handed weapons deal the same damage per hit as one-handers but deal it MUCH MUCH slower. If you find yourself favoring marksman or sniper in most of the games you play, you won't be wanting to in Tree of Life. Archery is currently broken (at least that is what it appears to be) and is not a viable weapon to use. Using a mid-tier bow that does about 10-20 damage and using arrows that deal 20-40 damage, your shots will probably do about 12 damage to top tier monsters and about 18 to low tier ones. That sort of damage is about as much as I could deal tickling a hippopotamus and that doesn't even account for the speed of firing a bow and the high energy required to fire. Ontop of that, targeting on the bow is terrible. Instead of accounting for arrow-drop or for calculating distance, you just look at your target until they are highlighted and fire. While this may favor people with low skill (as in actual aiming dexterity and not level sort of skill) it is flawed even there because you can accidently target walls, trees, and structures that your target is standing near, which will make you a target for the neutral arrow towers nearby.

Bandaging
To get health back quickly in the middle of a fight, bandages are the tool for the job. To use a bandage, simply select it by hitting the correct key in your hotbar and dragging your cursor over to the icon by holding down right click. Once you have used a bandage, there will be a short cooldown before you can use any other healing/food item.

Running
To escape combat or move away quickly, you will need to sprint. Sprinting can be achieved by double tapping the W" key. Once you start to sprint
date: you will drain your energy at about 100 per second. Now this is a problem because while you are fighting
recommended: you are also using energy to attack
hoursPlayed: so temporarily retreating to bandage is a costly move when fighting players. Beyond using it for combat
voteText:
it is mostly useless for moving around because most people can only sprint for around 2-3 seconds before they are out of energy and then must wait for it to slowly recharge.


Building
As was previously mentioned
helpfulPercent: Tree of Life is most similiar to Archeage
votesHelpful: and building is the biggest reason for that. Building can be seperated into three categories as well: Defensive Buildings
votesTotal: Utility Buildings
votesFunny:
and Building Construction.

Defensive Buildings
Walls
commentsCount: gates
column16: fences
column17: and archer towers are all the defensive buildings in this game. Walls and gates come in two tiers: stone and wood. Fences have three tiers and archer towers have two tiers. The defensive buildings are things to be set up and forgotten about until they stop working. Defending your base from a raid is not very fun because the towers are doing most of the work while you can't even see the people attacking you because walls are so tall. The building themselves are not bad because bases are usually only raided when no one is playing
column18: so having a defensive system that doesn't require sleep is great
column19:
but it still takes away alot of the fun that is to be had when you defend against a raid or even when you are the one raiding!

Utility Buildings
Utility Buildings consists of crafting stations
column20: wells
column21: and storage units/shops
column22: or in other words
column23: every thing that is not a defensive building. Crafting stations are often take on the appearance of things like blacksmith's hut
column24: carpentry buildings
column25: and crafting/cooking tables. These are nothing special and can be operated by placing the required components for a recipe into the building and then clicking on the icon to craft that item. Wells passively create water bottles which can be used in crafting or can be drunk to recover some energy. Storage units
column27:
are used to store things and shops can be used to sell things!

Construction
Of course the biggest part of building is actually building. To build all those "wonderful" structures
column28: you will need to gather resources such as firewood
column32: and fat. Once you have gathered these
column33: then you can craft a blueprint which can be placed to construct an area were the structure can be made. After this
column34: you or your friends will need to carry heavy logs and stones slowly to the construction site before you can make banging noises with a hammer while the items needed to actually build the structure are sucked from your bag one.... by one.... until finally your structure is a usable building. This sort of building system may create uniformity
column35:
bans creativity. The buildings are all predesigned and all take an annoyingly long time to build if you have no one to help you.


Farming
Farming does not just apply to crops
column36: it also applies to the gathering of resources. Mining in Tree of Life is like most MMO's. Ore nodes spawn randomly in a zone and can be punched with your bare fist to mine them. Forestry consists of punching a tree to it has no health and then picking up the sapling and putting it back down and then either punching the log into firewood or carrying it slowly to some place. Planting crops requires you to MAKE a crop plot and then place it down
column37: and then slowly seed each plot. Harvesting those crops amounts to slowly hand picking each plot until only a few plants are left
column38:
and then PICKING UP the PLOTS of the remaining plants to get seeds through a bug because harvesting plants doesn't give enough seeds to be sustainable. Fishing is incredibly boring and requires no interaction once you cast the line. Ranching (Caring for Animals) is somewhat lacking because all that must be done to an animal to get products from it is to feed it the correct feed bag and then wait about a minute or two for it to poop out something like milk or antlers. The only thing you really need to do to keep your animals alive is give them medicine when they get sick (and they don't get sick very often).


Overall
column39: the game at this state is very lacking and I would suggest that you do not buy it YET."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay this is a review for tree of life.

Tree of life is a game where you can build, buildings with a leveling system. Simple as that. Or is it?

I'll quickly talk about the games progression.

The first thing you may want to do is, Punch trees (Minecraft? Ark?) alot of games have this system now.
Punching trees will give you twigs, apples and eventually a log.
Punching the log will give you firewood.
With the twigs you can craft torches with E [Putting the twigs into your inventory] (this is to get your tinkering" up and so you have a light source at the night.

Torches can also be used to light campfires (you must create one to survive and cook food)

It took me a while to figure out how to consume food... You must right click+Drag to consume the food.

From there you can figure it out.

Since the game is Multiplayer
date:
expect to work together (if you can) or not (if you have a language barrier).
Play with friends and the progress will be alot better.

Theres also a level cap in the game. As you will have a limited amount of points you can spend. (which is kind of stupid).
Most people in this game will want to work alone (i haven't seen a single person talk within the game).

If you die. You become a spooky ghost. Spooky! There is a cooldown for you to ressurect
recommended:
you can shorten it from consuming soul shards from Skelebobs.

This game is fun. I would recommend this.
However
hoursPlayed: i probably won't play it anymore in a while as i have other games that require my attention.\nIf this game had a single player i would probably play it more."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's okay. I'm a littled bored by it now. It was fun learning how to play, building a base, and advancing skills. But now I'm pretty burned out by it and it's starting to feel more like a chore than anything else.

So here is how the game works at the moment and this is why I say it feels like a chore.

You build a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• base somewhere. It's nice though, it's home. You might fish for food, you might kill bear, or you might find crab on the beach. While you're slowly improving your home, you're leveling up skills. After a few levels, your base doesn't have to be ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• anymore. You can build wooden walls around your home to keep intruders and monsters out. But you'll also need Arrow towers to defend your walls from anyone/anything that trys to destroy your walls. Well, arrow towers need arrows. So go spend an hour making arrows. But that was kinda boring, so you log out for the day. Tomorrow you log back on, and there are a few holes in the wall. You repair them, and you check why the wall wasn't defended. Maybe you need more arrow towers, or maybe your towers ran out of arrows over night. So you go make more arrows. But that was kinda boring, so you log out for the day.

Wash, rinse, repeat.

Don't get me wrong. This was a fun game up until I realized I'd have to put time into it every day if I wanted to be able to function the following days.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is just awesome! It kills your free time in insane volumes! I'm really looking forward for all this new content it might have once it's released! Koreans know how to make games :)
Core things that I like:
+ Lots of different content: many animals, buildings, items etc.
+ Really nice system of skill advancement: you advance in what you use, and those skill improve your stats.
+ Great mix of an RPG and a sandbox!
Though there are some cons in the current state of development. But I'm sure they will be solved in future updates:
- Lots of content is yet not implemented, but the game can be enjoyed for days even now
- This game is super grindy. You will spend hours and hours just felling trees.
- It is really hard to play alone or with one or two friends. You better have a large community with you - then you can rule the lands! :) And build a decent base.

In general, for all those who loves sandboxes, this one is a sure pick!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI absolutely love this game. There have been few games that hold my attention for long, the last one being Archeage. I'm seeing a trend with Korean games... I think the best part is that the devs are actively improving the game by fixing bugs and listening to community suggestions. I think the best features in the game is the ability to design your own base and have shops all over the map where you can sell your wares. You can also go fishing, cook your food for yourself and others, craft torches, lanterns so that you can see in the dark. You can steal from cabins/tents with lockpicking or people who don't lock their cabins/tents up. You can practically build anywhere on the map, live anywhere you want. You can become a traveling trader and make money doing trade deals with guilds and individuals. You can pick up animals and bring them to your base. There is a lot of things to do that will keep you occupied for awhile. Great job on the game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: Get game if you like survival and friends, dont get game if you don't like surviving or friends

This game is similar to other Survival RPGs in the way you are just dropped in and told Survive". Combat is simple and just involves mashing mouse clicks (Holding the mouse is slower for weapons like daggers).

The constantly progressing server makes it so that maintanence is required for things like your base and all your work stations because monsters tend to be able to spawn inside the walls of the base.

The pvp is fair in my opinion
date: punishing those who attack other players or thier possessions with the "red" status
recommended: putting a target on those who do things that seem morally wrong. (Though it does seem a bit excessive that destorying 2 buildings would be a 4 hour red status).\n\nIf you plan on buying tree of life
hoursPlayed: it is highly recommended that you start with a group of friends and in those 2 hours before losing the ability to refund it
voteText:
have a goal in mind because the game is not going to give you one. Friends are a nessessity because the whole aspect of just grinding/farming materials is grueling. The amount or resources needed to build anything of substance is Too damn high (meme intended) for just a single person to endure.

A recommendation i would have for the game is that the traces of evil should be more substantial instead of just inventory trash. Maybe have an option to forgive the person and immediately remove their red status or give an option to track down the mother fornicater who wrecked your wall and stole "yo ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•".

Overall
helpfulPercent: having fun with the game with a group of friends
votesHelpful: looking forward to more content
votesTotal: and hopefully a positive release.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is as promising as the next adventure games. I just hope that the climax doesn't drop as soon as one has built an awesome village... As of now, this seems to be an issue. Games like these needs the climax to keep rising, even after the main excitement has been experienced...

Unfortunately for this game, this seems to be a major issue. This leads to other people revolting in the game and destroys everything they see.

If this game doesn't get a mission option soon, or, different level system throughout the world (meaning the monsters get tougher in different regions), the game will not satisfy players.

I enjoy what they've done so far and I really hope that they'll fix these issues before this world becomes all dark.

Found a settlement with two gates on it. My friend and I built 2 walls in front of each gate and an arrow tower right next to each one. If they attacked the walls, they would become criminals and be shot by the towers. Long story short, we gave the two inhabitants 10+ hours criminal time and for some inexplicable reason they destroyed their own base.

10/10 would buy again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[REVIEW FOR LEFT HAND PLAYERS]

Tree Of Life is a great little survival game, but it's small issues where hard to overlook when I discovered that the game did not support key binding. (as of May)

As a left hand player, I have to rebind keys for every game I play.
In order to try TOL, I had to force a keyboard script with Autohotkey to mirror the WASD keys to the bottom right, witch allowed me to gain control at the expense of not being able to use the WASD keys.
By the time I could successfully play the game, I couldnt not embrase the experence knowing I was playing on a hack job script that would often intearfear with the games sprint control and lock me into moving forward.

Since I payed the current full price of $20 I had to ask for a refund.
I intend to try the game again when we can rebind controls, but I will wait for it to go on sale.
